Title: Dyslexia and Learning Style: a practitioner's handbook (2nd Edn)
AdditionalInformation: This second edition of a rigorous, research-informed textbook, includes substantial new findings from an empirical study which aimed to examine associations between dyslexia and a particular processing style or preference for a specific mode of presentation in lectures.  Using Riding’s Cognitive Style Analysis (CSA) as an analytical tool, the author conducted a quantitative control trial with 118 male higher education students, 60 with dyslexia and 58 without, matched for course studied and academic year. A lecture was presented to participants with and without visual reinforcements and answers to comprehension questions were compared across the two groups to measure the impact of mode of presentation on retention of information, across both dyslexic and non-dyslexic control participants. ANOVA and multiple regression analyses revealed no relationship between lecture scores when presentation mode was matched with the individual’s style category as measured on the verbaliser/ imager dimension of the CSA for either dyslexic or control group. Chapters 2 and 6 of this second edition have been substantially re-written in the light of the author’s further research, with chapter 5 (p.91) making explicit reference to the above study.  The theoretical position of this second edition has thus shifted in the light of new evidence, rendering it significantly different from the first edition.

The Role of the Adult in Early Years Settings
AdditionalInformation: This textbook, of which Rose is the principal author, is informed by an original theoretical framework - the ‘plural practitioner’ - which emerged from her empirical study of 100 student practitioners on a sector-endorsed ‘Top Up’ BA degree in Early Childhood Studies, together with a systematic review of the literature. She used focus group discussions explored the student practitioners’ insights into their role in providing quality practice. The methodology was interpretive, with both deductive and inductive approaches employed to analyse the qualitative, narrative data sets, which were correlated to the literature.  Although data analysis was shared by the authors, the bulk of work was undertaken by Rose and she created the concept of ‘the plural practitioner’.  Once the framework had been compiled, a ‘member check’ was conducted via a questionnaire (analysed using descriptive statistics) which was utilised to validate the framework. This final analysis was undertaken by Rose. The book also drew on a second piece of research, developed by Rose, which underpinned a key theme explored throughout the book in relation to adult roles, namely ‘child and adult initiated activities’.  A different purposive sample was used of 100 experienced early years practitioners who were undertaking the Early Years Practitioner Status (EYPS) qualification. The research design and methodology mirrored the first project and the analytical process followed the same route (recorded focus group discussions to generate reflective discourse and the use of grounded theory, narrative and content analysis to interrogate the data). A review of the findings from this second study is outlined in the book.

DoubleWeightingStatement: The book Teacher Development in Action reports the doctoral research findings of a year long ethnographically informed study of EFL teachers in Slovakia. The study utilised longitudinal mixed methods to explore the impact of an experiential in-service teacher development course drawing on L2 motivation theory, group dynamics, and educational psychology. Quantitative (pre- and post-test questionnaires measuring students' perceptions of their classroom environment) and qualitative (regular course feedback, teacher interviews, lesson observations, and field notes) measures were employed to assess the course impact on cognitive and behavioural change of self-selected non-native EFL teachers in Slovakia.

Title: Beyond the Personal Learning Environment: attachment and control in the classroom of the future
IMS Question & Test Interoperability Overview, 2.1 Final Specification.
AdditionalInformation:
IMS Question & Test Interoperability is the world’s only open specification for computer aided assessment material. IEC elicited and edited significant input from a UK higher education development and practice community that was funded by Jisc. The basic research process that underpinned the development of the specification involved gathering use cases from communities of practice, soliciting candidate data structures that addressed the use cases, direct pilot implementation of the candidate structures, build consensus around those same candidate structures and record the outcome in draft specification documents. 

After the original leaders of the IMS QTI Working Group moved on, we assumed leadership and brought to completion the latest version, 2.1. IEC, through Kraan, was formally one of three IMS working group co-chairs, but quickly became the editor of the specification. That meant that IEC assumed the chairing of the weekly working group calls, controlled development of the specification through the issue tracker that was central to the research and development process and wrote the changes into a master copy of the document set. IEC was also instrumental in liaising between the various companies and communities across Europe, North America, Asia and the Pacific who have a stake in the specification. IEC also contributed and tested several new data structures, and applied our experience of holding interoperability testing events by organising the first public demonstrations of QTI 2.1 interoperability.

In our recent survey, QTI 2.1 was found to be an integral part of more than a quarter of a billion pounds’ worth of assessment system investment worldwide. There is also evidence that most major US educational publishers and assessment boards have switched to QTI 2.1. as their internal exchange format for assessment material.

Title:
IEEE Standard for Learning Technology— Conceptual Model for Resource Aggregation for Learning, Education, and Training.
IEEE Std 1484.13.1-2012.
AdditionalInformation:
The IEEE RAMLET standard is both a conceptual model and a formal ontology that abstracts across the structures of a number of different content aggregation formats. The standard enables a predictable means of transcoding a content aggregation instance from one format to another in a wide variety of ways, including database schemas, XSL transformations and SPARQL queries.

Both the idea of using a formal global-as-view model as well as the decision to use the W3C semantic web technology standards were IEC’s contribution, through the work of Kraan. The impetus for the strict global-as-view model arose from IEC’s earlier research on interoperability specifications in general, and our experience with profiling specifications in particular. The danger of trying to make a specification that abstracts over many existing specifications is that it simply ends up adding yet another specification. Limiting RAMLET to the semantics of existing specifications, and only defining the relations between them, solved that problem. This approach could well be applicable to other interoperability specification areas. 

Using our research expertise in semantic web technologies gave the RAMLET group the required formal precision to express the model, as well as the flexibility to accommodate a wide variety of content aggregation specifications to map to and from. IEC was the author and editor of the OWL ontology that represents the RAMLET model. IEC also provided proof-of-concept implementation research.

Title:
Recommended Practice for Learning Technology - IETF RFC 4287 - Atom Syndication Format - Mapping to the Conceptual Model for Resource Aggregation.
IEEE Recommended practice P1484.13.5.
AdditionalInformation:
The Atom recommended practice for RAMLET specifies exactly how to map instances of the IETF Atom content syndication format to the terms of the RAMLET core ontology. By using the practice, any technique that maps Atom to RAMLET becomes predictable.

Both the idea of including the Atom syndication format as well as the mapping work itself were contributions from IEC. Atom is slightly unusual for a content aggregation format in that it is not primarily used for static compressed content archives. Nonetheless, IEC’s research into digital repository interoperability, Open Educational Resource (OER) sharing practices and system integration in further and higher education institutions suggested that Atom was used widely to create and share educational content aggregations. In practice, the mapping to the RAMLET core ontology confirmed a high degree of overlap with other content aggregation formats.

In addition to the Atom format, IEC also contributed the IMS Content Packaging mapping to the IEEE RAMLET set of recommended practices, and provided help in the realisation of the remaining formats. IEC made a strong contribution to the development of IMS Content Packaging prior to this REF period.

The Child as Social Person
AdditionalInformation:
This output synthesises a diverse literature using a major theoretical model to provide structure, while retaining the integrity of the different disciplines discussed.  The result is a text that has been hailed as representing its material in a way that is accessible to students while also thought-provoking to experienced scholars.  The subject matter is the social development of children and how models not just from psychology but from across a range of biological and social sciences contribute to understanding it.

Research questions
What, explicitly, is the current state of understanding in developmental psychology of children as social persons?  
What contribution does Bronfenbrenner’s account of children’s development through social contexts make to integrating disparate theoretical approaches?  
How does understanding based on one disciplinary approach become modified by evidence from other disciplines?

Methodology
The principal method of data collection was extensive critical reading.  Online databases (for example MIMAS’ Web of Knowledge) were searched using key terms and key authors, and journals which appeared frequently in these searches were read systematically.  The criteria applied for inclusion of found items included theoretical importance, quality of the research, interdisciplinary relevance, links to other items and importance for practice, especially in education.

The resulting text appears to provide a robust structure through which to represent children’s social development, and both a critical overview of a broad area and precise referencing to sources.

Means of dissemination
The book sought to present both the research base and the relevant theory with the challenges that face teachers, parents and professional psychologists in mind.  It was published by a major international psychology publisher and marketed to researchers, lecturers and students in developmental psychology and associated disciplines.

Title: Vers le contrôle pluriel de l’École ? : La nature changeante du pouvoir dans le système éducatif anglais
EnglishAbstract: The article examines the control and evaluation of the English education system over the last twenty years. It is argued that prior to the Education Reform Act of 1988, the education system could be described as a partnership between Government, schools and teachers – in which a combination of professionalism and bureaucratic rationality provided overall control.The article argues that the raft of policy initiatives since then have involved both increased central control yet also greater institutional autonomy. The authors argue the need for a new, multi-dimensional, model of educational control based on constrained autonomy, whilst empowering new educational partners.

Title: Developing Expertise: How Enactivism Re-frames Mathematics Teacher Development
VolumeTitle: ZDM – The International Journal on Mathematics Education
AdditionalInformation:
This output was developed into a journal paper after an invitation, because of my enactivist framework that has informed my practice and research for nearly 20 years, to contribute to the ZDM Special Issue related to Teacher expertise. This innovative paper, developed with long-term collaborator Coles, was described by reviewers as changing the landscape and practices in mathematics teacher development and forms part of a collection of our papers that look at how concepts in the teaching and learning of mathematics are seen and enacted through this worldview.
Research questions
What principles inform the practice of supporting teacher development through collaborative groups which include both novices and experts? 
What norms for discussion are developed in such a collaborative group?
Methodology
Interrogation of current practice in mathematics education teaching, both pre-service and in-service, at the University of Bristol to distil principles that underpin the effective practices commented on by external examiners.
A collaborative group, funded by the NCETM and focused on the work of Caleb Gattegno had audio-recordings taken of all meetings. A key methodological strategy was to report on a conversation (between the novices identifying common influences in how they had learnt) at the end of the project, then tracking back through the data to see how this happened.
Analysis
For the common experiences, we track back in the data to look for patterns over time. The focus here is on – finding a purpose, using purposes and acting from a purpose, which novices and experts were all able to do.
Means of dissemination
Dissemination is through our practice of teacher education, using collaborative groups for Masters and PGCE work, and, most recently, a collaborative group of PhD students. We wrote a paper that was accepted for the prestigious Task Design ICMI 22 study, which shares and extends these principles.

Title: Thorns on my tongue
VolumeTitle: Changing English: Studies in Culture and Education
AdditionalInformation:
This output continues a long-term line of investigation of pedagogy through close observation of classroom interaction. The specific events addressed in the paper arose during invited professional development work in a London secondary school researching alongside teachers in their classrooms and reflecting on patterns of teacher-learner interaction captured on video.

Research questions
Where do regularities and tensions between teachers’ and learners’ discourse and actions appear in establishing and completing lesson tasks?
How is agency (control of learning) distributed in successful task process?
How might we account for disturbances and counter-activity in task process?

Methodology
Data were collected by video, fieldnote observation and post-observation discussion with teachers of the video record. The affordances and constraints of video recording within lessons are considered, as is the shifting engagement of a practitioner-researcher who intervenes in teaching for professional development purposes. Research literature in the field of cultural-historical activity theory is reviewed, specifically with regard for the definition and critique of the concept of ‘activity system’ (Cole and Engeström, 1992). The concept of ‘counteraction’ (Poddiakov, 2001) is appropriated and extended in order to explain tensions between learner’s activity and teacher’s activity. Broadly, the sociocultural method of observing mediation closely and accounting for developmental change is maintained (Vygotsky, 1986; Wertsch, 1991). 

Means of dissemination
Early reflections on developing teaching competence were shared with teachers on the research site over three years (2004-2006) and in researcher’s initial teacher training work until 2011. A draft of the paper was presented at international conference (International Society for Cultural Activity Research, University of Seville, 2005). A summary of findings was presented and discussed at the UK and Ireland regional meeting of ISCAR at Bath University, 2009. Further investigation of counteraction is ongoing and a subsequent paper was presented at ISCAR Conference in Rome, 2011.

The project drew on the energy of 14 research collaborators, organized though a socio-cultural model of learning.  The role of Ros Sutherland was pivotal to this work. EnglishAbstract: This article draws on empirical data from two comparative studies (McNess 2002, Osborn et al. 2002) to dicuss, from an 'outsider's' point of view, the underlying values that can be identified in the priorities and practice of teachers in the Danish Folkeskole. The New Regionalism in African Education: Limits and Possibilities
VolumeTitle: South-South Co-operation and Transfer in Education and Development
AdditionalInformation:
The original research on which this output is based arose from an elaborated form of systematic review of the literature funded by the Department for International Development (DfID).  This focused on Globalisation, Education and Development: Ideas, actors and dynamics.

Research questions
To examine the relationship between globalisation, education and development based upon a review of policies and programmes developed at supranational level (global and regional) that have implications for meeting the Millenium Development Goals in Africa and other low income regions; to review the literature on current policies intended to alleviate deepening poverty and inequality of access to infrastructures and public services.

Methodology
The elaborated review methodology developed for the project is called CoSCAr, i.e. the review was Comprehensive (brought together literature in different languages, genres, methodological and theoretical paradigms and grey literature); Systematic (synthesised literature in relation to key themes),  Critical (sought to make explicit and examine the rigour of underlying theoretical and methodological assumptions); and, Accessible (presented in a variety of different formats for different audiences).

Means of dissemination
The published version of the final report was complemented by working papers, policy briefings, journal articles and book chapters on specific aspects of the project - in this case the impact of the new regionalism on education in Africa. The chapter drew on theory of new regionalism developed within international relations which was used to frame discussion of the development of educational regions in Africa. The chapter contributed to a collection of essays on the topic of South-South collaboration in education.

Title: Key Dimensions of Effective Leadership: a Study of Township and Rural Schools in South Africa
Social Justice, Capabilities and the Quality of Education in Low Income Countries
AdditionalInformation:
The research to which this output relates was a six year research programme on the quality of education in low income countries (EdQual) funded by the Department for International Development.  The article was an attempt to develop new theoretical understanding of the concept of education quality in terms of social justice and human capabilities in a way that was commensurate with the aims of the programme.

Research questions
To develop new knowledge and understanding to assist policy makers, practitioners and the international development community to implement new initiatives to improve the quality of education for disadvantaged groups of learners in difficult delivery contexts.

Methodology
The EdQual research programme consortium was led by the University of Bristol and included partners in the Universities of Bath, Cape Coast (Ghana), Dar es Salaam (Tanzania), Witwatersrand (South Africa), de la Frontera (Chile), Aga Khan (Pakistan) and the Kigali Institute of Education (Rwanda). The programme adopted mixed methods to develop a holistic understanding of education quality. It undertook secondary analysis of the Southern African Consortium for Monitoring Education Quality (SACMEQ) data set to develop multi-level statistical models of education quality. This was complemented by intervention studies including participant action research in the areas of language and literacy, school leadership, science and mathematics curriculum change and the use of ICTs in education. The EdQual consortium built capacity in partner organisations through collaborative working arrangements and through sponsoring PhDs in areas related to the research.

Means of dissemination
The findings from EdQual were published in numerous working papers, journal articles, conference proceedings and in an edited book. This was an introductory article to a special edition of the International Journal of Educational Development that drew together key findings from the research programme and sought to frame them within a social justice and human capabilities approach.

Title: Misurare in Cabri è sempre un vantaggio?
VolumeTitle: L'insegnamento della matematica e delle scienze integrate
EnglishAbstract: The article develops an original model for classifying and using measuring tools in a dynamic geometry software, that draws on previous original work about the dragging tool. Through the analysis of secondary school students’ problem solving activities in the context of proving in geometry, we show that measuring has the potential to support proving by stimulating the formulation of a conjecture or the construction of a proof, but in some cases it may hinder the proving process by keeping students’ attention on perceptive elements of the figure. Implications for practical use of the model and software are drawn.
AdditionalInformation: The article develops an original model for classifying and using measuring tools in a dynamic geometry software, that draws on previous original work about the dragging tool. Developing "deliberate analysis" for learning mathematics and for mathematics teacher education: how the enactive approach to cognition frames reflection
AdditionalInformation:
This output was developed into a journal paper from a contribution to the invitation only Mathematics Education and Contemporary Theory conference, to which I was invited because of my enactivist framework.  Enactivism has been referred to as a paradigm-shifting worldview. This paper forms part of a collection of papers, developed by Laurinda Brown and Alf Coles out of a longitudinal collaboration since 1995, that look at how concepts are seen and enacted through this worldview. The paper advances theory by taking a critical look at reflection from the other side of a paradigm shift.
Research questions
From an enactive approach to cognition, we work on the question “how do we do reflecting?”
Methodology
Linking theory and practice is at the heart of enactivist thinking since all learning is seen as doing. We look at the practice of teacher education and individual teachers who have developed as teachers through this practice. We work with student teachers and teachers so that they stay with the detail of their experience. We use transcripts, writing from the teachers about issues in their teaching and field-notes.
Analysis
We analyse the data through the framework of Varela’s concept of “deliberate analysis”. Given the enactivist stance, integrity, coherence and consistency are evidenced through the braiding of first and third-person accounts.
Means of dissemination
Responding to invitations to work with staff and students at the University of Agder, Norway (October 2012) and Monash University, Australia (August, 2012) on enactivist ideas in relation to the teaching and learning of mathematics. There is an entry in the on-line Springer Encyclopedia of Mathematics Education entitled Enactivist Theories. In this writing, my work is identified as being influential, including reference to this ESM paper. Mainly, though, our dissemination is through our developing practice with pre- and in-service teachers of mathematics.

Title: My neighbourhood: Studying perceptions of urban space and neighbourhood with moblogging
Being alongside : For the teaching and learning of mathematics
AdditionalInformation:
This book addresses the following research questions: how does a teacher create a classroom environment in which students can be creative and independent in their learning of mathematics? how does a teacher leader create a department environment in which teachers can be creative and independent in their learning about teaching mathematics, in particular, making use of video recordings of lessons? what is the same or different about answers to these first two questions?

The book is a report of an ESRC funded study, which adopted an enactivist methodology. What this means in practice is that the aim of research is to uncover theories that are 'good enough for' their users. Multiple views of data are taken and there is a cycling process of data collection and analysis. Video recordings were taken of the lessons of one exceptional teacher in one innovative mathematics department in the UK, over a two year period. These recordings were analysed to answer the first research question. There were two cycles of analysis, the first looking at patterns in the use of words, the second looking in more detail at the role of the teacher. These video recordings were also used by me (I was head of the department at the time) in department meetings with staff at the same school. Audio recordings were taken of these sessions and they were analysed to answer the second research question, again, there were two cycles of analysis.

In terms of dissemination, articles taken from this book have appeared in two journals (Journal of Mathematics Teacher Education, For the Learning of Mathematics) and a third article is in preparation for the journal ZDM. I presented the key ideas from the book at a session during the day conference of the British Society for Research into Learning Mathematics (March, 2013).

Title: Ethical imperialism or ethical mindfulness? Rethinking ethical review for social sciences
AdditionalInformation:
This output draws upon and synthesises academic and scholarly reflection on 6 years experience of leading the introduction of systematic support for social science research ethics in a research-intensive university. 

Research questions
How can ethical review be undertaken for social science research in ways that support knowledge generation across the full range of applicable research methodologies? 
What are the obstacles to and opportunities for achieving reviews that enhance ethical practice? 
What conceptual framework helps to explain the current mixed experiences of social scientists?
What strategies have been adopted at the selected university to counteract adverse effects and promote positive ethical engagement by social science researchers?

This article is a response to Zachary Schrag’s rebuttal of  ‘ethics review in social sciences’ and his challenge that ‘the burden of proof for its continuation rests on its defenders’ (Schrag, 2011).

Methodology
There are three strands involved gathering and analysing the material that underpins this article:
•	Critical reflection on the implementation of policy and practice – critically reflective practice - analysis of 'warrant'
•	The latest developments in ethics that approach ethical practice as social constructs and cultural tools. The analysis was informed by dialogue with research-active academics during policy consultations and by formal and informal interviews with researchers during their preparation for ethical review
•	‘Writing as research’ within qualitative inquiry and inspired by the ethicist, Robert J. Nash  (2004) Liberating Scholarly Writing. 

Means of dissemination
The dialogical testing of ideas in this article required dissemination prior to publication at university workshops, and a public lecture Research Ethics: one size fits all? This process has continued at events organised by the University Research Enterprise and Development, at the University of Malta, and most recently at the Welsh Senior Research Leaders Programme run by the Leadership Foundation for the Welsh government and HEFCW.

Title: Towards a postcolonial research ethics in comparative and international education
Confidentiality and Record Keeping in Counselling and Psychotherapy
AdditionalInformation:
Confidentiality and record-keeping are one of the most rapidly developing areas of law and the most common source of dilemmas for counsellors where privacy competes with other ethical imperatives. This is the first text to take a systematic overview of legal and ethical issues for this profession. 
The law is viewed as a form of authoritative public ethical discourse designed to structure and regulate human activity but not necessarily coherently nor free of uncertainty, ambiguity and ethical dilemmas.
Research questions
-What are the current opinions and legal/ethical issues that most concern counsellors about these topics?
- What is the applicable law – where this can be established?
Methodology 
1.Quotations from practitioners at the start of chapters have been systematically selected to represent the range of professional views expressed in 2. 
2.A series of ten workshops and consultations were held over the preceding three years in the four countries of the UK to capture the current ethical and legal issues facing practitioners. Some issues were followed up by interviews, email exchanges and other communications.
3.A quantitative analysis was undertaken of issues raised with the relevant professional help line.
4.Legal analysis, mainly based on original sources of law, was the main strategy for establishing the applicable law using forensic reasoning and to identify areas of uncertainty or conflicting views.
5.The organisation of the text was based on a thematic analysis of 1-4.
The lead author (Bond) was responsible for about 70% of analysis and writing drawing over 15 years of researching these topics and related professional practice and consultancy.
Dissemination
- On-going consultations at events and workshops to communicate findings but also to gather professional and legal data for a new edition – currently being written
- Over 3,200 copies sold mainly in UK but also Australia, New Zealand and USA

Title: The possibility and importance of postperspectival working
Introduction (Creative approaches to improving participation)
VolumeTitle: Creative approaches to improving participation : Giving learners a say
AdditionalInformation:
This output is the introductory chapter to an edited book written for teachers and creative practitioners and by them. The chapter draws on an 18 month research project that explored how one organization, the flagship English ‘creative learning’ programme Creative Partnerships (CP) (2002-2011), attempted to ‘put young people at the heart’ of its work. The chapter provides an overview of the literature and presents some of the findings of the research undertaken. 

Research questions
What is the ‘participatory turn’ in relation to young people in schools and how has it been enacted in different contexts?
What are the benefits for schools in adopting creative approaches to participation?
What kinds of processes and practices of youth participation emerge in creative activities?

Methodology
Data collection:
Interviews (with CP personnel, staff in schools, creative agents or practitioners and students) – transcripts were produced
Observations in schools and at events, focus groups and ‘shadowing’ students, in twelve CP regions – ethnographic fieldnotes were produced
Collection of documentary evidence including eg photographs, minutes, schools’ & CP reports, publications, evaluations, multi-media productions, school application forms.

Analysis involved textual analysis, using established methods from cultural studies, of a large amount of documentary evidence. In addition, interview transcripts and fieldnotes were coded and patterns across the data in reference to ‘youth participation’ pulled out. A taxonomy of youth participation in CP was produced to assist with data analysis.

Means of dissemination
The book was written as a resource for teachers to help them to run participatory arts activities in their schools. The book has been sold nationally and internationally to academics working in the field and to teachers and creative practitioners working in schools.  The work was also presented at national and international practitioner and academic conferences.

EnglishAbstract: This paper examines the range and extent of school effectiveness in China, where little previous evidence exists, thereby contributing to the international knowledge base.  Original evidence from an ESRC/DFID funded project demonstrate significant differences in senior school effectiveness using data collected from over 90,000 students in three regions. The findings indicate Value Added measures can provide a useful measure of educational quality in China and this approach is seen by stakeholders as more scientific and a welcome addition to current methods of evaluating Chinese schools and teachers.  However, local contexts in China and methodological limitations also need to be considered.

Title: Creative designs for learning
The ethics of research : Enhancing knowledge and being ethically mature
VolumeTitle: Ethical Maturity in the Helping Professions : Making Difficult Life and Work Decisons
AdditionalInformation:
This output examines the complexity of ethical judgements involved in social science research for the helping professions. This academic essay is located within an extended study of ethical maturity to support difficult life and work decisions. Ethical maturity is not viewed as a developmental state that once achieved can be secured for all circumstances. Instead, ethical maturity is defined as a state marked by a number of characteristics and qualities. This chapter is the penultimate chapter and seeks to open up the readers’ awareness of the variability and complexity of factors involved in research ethics.
Key questions:
The essay is shaped around answering:
•How has our current understanding of research ethics been shaped by past ethical crises in undertaking research?
•What ethical warrants, i.e. claims to moral authority, have shaped different approaches to research ethics?
•How do approaches to key issues vary internationally?
•What sort of judgements might be required of an ethically mature researcher beyond the standardised ethical reviews and procedural practices developed for biomedical and experimental laboratory-based research? 
Methodologies:
•	Historical case studies, often based on extensive study of original sources but cited with examples from reliable and accessible sources
•Ethnographic analysis and reflection to prompt and support analysis of differentiating issues and establish the human context of research in social sciences
•Analytically-based synthesis around key themes and to provide a structure for the argumentation underpinning the essay – methodologically originating in philosophical and theological systematics but repositioned as epistemologically socially constructive and secular
Modes of dissemination:
•Locally – ideas tested and disseminated in seminars, lectures and in discussions with researchers in my role as Faculty Research Ethics Officer for Law and Social Sciences
•Nationally – at the Academy for Social Sciences ‘Generic Ethics Principles for Social Science Research’ 
•Internationally – Visiting Professor University for Malta and conferences

Title: Beyond Methodological 'Isms' in Comparative Education in an Era of Globalisation
Professionalism and Pedagogy: a contemporary opportunity
AdditionalInformation:
This output is a culmination of TLRP’s work to synthesise understanding of pedagogy.  This began with TLRP’s conferences and thematic activities, and was represented for public engagement through ‘evidence-informed principles’.  This specific research addressed the tacit nature of much teacher knowledge, and sought to harvest, synthesise and re-present the conceptual language of expert teachers.

Research questions
What, explicitly, are the most powerful pedagogic concepts on which expert teachers draw?
Is it possible to represent and promote teacher expertise for a 21st century future through the identification of such concepts?

Methodology
There were two parallel strands of data collection.
•	Research literature on teacher discourse, conceptualisation and classroom practice was reviewed. Complementing this during 2008-10, ethnographic methods recorded pedagogic representations at academic seminars and conferences, including BERA, EERA, APERA and AERA.  
•	Practising teachers were extensively consulted.  In particular, a programme of teacher workshops, organised by GTC-E, explored the research questions through discussion and analysis of teacher-led case-studies of routine classroom practice. This work was also discussed at meetings of GTC-NI, GTC-S and at an international conference of GTCs convened by GTC-W.

Analysis was challenging because of the volume and diversity of concepts produced. However, terms with particular relevance to curriculum, pedagogy and assessment were distinguished, and patterns of use were identified in relation to aims, context, processes and outcomes.  The resulting matrix appears to provide a robust structure through which to represent teacher expertise, irrespective of the particular concepts promoted.

Means of dissemination
The TLRP Commentary sought to present both the research base and knowledge of experienced teachers with contemporary challenges in mind.  40,000 copies were printed and distributed to UK schools and HEIs.  The GTCs featured the work in their magazines for teachers and it underpins future-orientated, professional textbooks on Reflective Teaching for early, school, further and higher education.

Title: Virtual and online research with young people
VolumeTitle: Research and Research Methods for Youth Practitioners
AdditionalInformation:
The chapter offers new insights to further our understanding of young people’s interactions in digital spaces – specifically from a methodological perspective. Despite the importance of online spaces to the lives of young people, digitally-based methodologies are still seen as problematic within wider mainstream educational research. The chapter uses original examples from a 6-year ethnographic study of an online gaming world. It explores some of the methodological and ethical tensions of working in digital space, and provides insights not only into how technological spaces might be conceived, but also how research within such arenas might be approached. 

In terms of originality, significance and rigour, the chapter extends previous research on virtual ethnography (e.g. Beer, 2007; Hine, 2005; Murthy, 2011) arguing that in research terms, digital and material spaces share similar characteristics. Using the case study as the ground for a methodological argument, the chapter suggests that many of the methodological anxieties around virtual methods could be avoided by drawing parallels with existing—and more accepted—material research practices. Despite nearly 15 years of scrutiny by a range of disciplines, there is still a paucity of academic writing that addresses methodological issues in researching digital spaces from the point of view of the education researcher. The chapter therefore makes a methodological contribution to the development of educational research in digital spaces.


References

Beer, D. and Burrows, R. (2007) Sociology and, of and in Web 2.0: Some Initial Considerations, Sociological Research Online, 12(5), 17.

Hine, C. (2005). Virtual Methods: Issues in Social Research on the Internet. Oxford, UK: Berg.

Murthy, D. (2008). Digital Ethnography: An examination of the use of new technologies for social research. Sociology, 42(5), 837-855.

AdditionalInformation: This article discusses, from the point of view of the evaluator, methodological issues relating to a two year evaluation of an intervention scheme, which provided deprived communities with weekly football training sessions run by professional football coaches. Rather than reporting on the findings of the intervention scheme itself, the article focuses on the difficulties in identifying quantifiable hard measures of impact for interventions such as these, owing to: the complex nature of the communities served; the limitations of attainable, short term outcomes; and the difficulties in identifying measurable outcomes. The paper also critically explores the understandings of ‘anti-social behaviour’ and interrogates the idea that this is a useful or measurable concept, including analysis of statistical data on anti-social behaviour.

Title: Thinking and Learning Through Drawing: in Primary Classrooms
AdditionalInformation: This book reflects the insights into the nature of design and technology that resulted from the author’s research. The focus of the research was young children’s use of drawing for designing technological artefacts and this required the analysis of a wide range of contexts in which children learn to design and make functional products. The centrality of modelling of ideas, whether through drawing, discussion or mock-ups, was a central tenet of the author’s thesis, which is reflected throughout the book. This research involved an examination of design drawings made by over 300 children aged 4-9 years, leading to a 2-year longitudinal comparative study of two Year 2 classes in a primary school in Kent, to ascertain improvements in designing through introducing a pedagogy based on the findings of the large-scale survey. Further details of the research process are discussed in the author’s output 3, ‘Taking ideas on a journey: researching designing in a Kent primary school.’

Title: Teaching Citizenship Education: A Radical Approach
AdditionalInformation: This research scrutinises the spaces between policy and practice in the teaching of Citizenship Education. It includes case studies conducted in schools in England and Scotland, and one from a Nigerian perspective, and other empirical data. The range of research approaches includes the collection and analysis of empirical data, autobiographical reflection, reportage, pupil insight; data were collected from nine schools, over 100 teachers and student teachers, and from pupils. All sources are regarded as illustrative rather than representative. Some analysis has been by the application of Interpretative Phenomenological Analysis (IPA), and all is conducted and evaluated within a social justice paradigm.

Title: Richard Rorty: une philosophie de l’éducation entre élitisme and conservatisme ?
EnglishAbstract: Richard Rorty's philosophy of education takes interest in the processes by which individuals in schools and universities develop their own characters. However, while each individual – pupil and student – has to deal with his/her beliefs and desires, only universities remain reliable for ensuring cultural renewal. This chapter aims at critically analysing Rorty’s philosophical positions in two different parts. First, it considers the main assumptions and inheritances of this pragmatism towards classical philosophies. Second, it investigates his understanding of "liberal hope" that should facilitate the decrease of cruelty as well as the development of human solidarity.

Title: Dewey, Durkheim : la discipline scolaire et le politique
EnglishAbstract: The topic “school discipline” developed by Durkheim in Moral Education illustrates the dominant framework in the French educational model. This paper considers the psychological and political dimensions of this topic, involving on the one hand Durkheim’s internalisation of basic moral principles and the development of citizenship and on the other hand Dewey’s concept of discipline, concerned with training moral characters. However, analysis of these different approaches does not just compare two political and cultural models, but also investigates the concept of "governmentality" advanced by Foucault, which may bring both authors together by assuming a common goal: the empowerment of individuals.

Title: La notion de croissance chez Dewey et Rorty
EnglishAbstract: American philosophers John Dewey and Richard Rorty agree in emphasising the necessary indeterminacy of the notion of 'growth' in order to leave evolutionary perspectives open. Their points of view diverge, however, when it comes to valorising the period of childhood. An analysis of the two conceptions of the 'ages of life’ allows the author to identify two philosophies of education. Rorty wishes to foreground literary education and the relations between teachers and students. For him the notion of growth finds its real home in the university, whereas Dewey highlights the importance of a general method applicable in all educational institutions.

Evaluating community-based interventions for young people: measuring the impact of informal mentoring
VolumeTitle: Journal of Poverty and Social Justice
AdditionalInformation: This article discussed the findings of a two year evaluation of an intervention scheme, which provided deprived communities with weekly football training sessions run by professional football coaches, in order to raise self-esteem, school attendance and attainment and reduce anti-social behaviour amongst young people. The article looks specifically at the importance of the informal mentoring role the football coaches provided to the young people and the overall social benefits of the scheme. It argues that the benefits of providing this level of support and establishing relationships built on trust are highly significant and discusses the importance of effective mentoring, informal relationships and friendships, referencing previous research exploring the importance of mentoring for developing resilience and self-efficacy.

Title: Creativity and Education Futures. Learning in a Digital Age.
DoubleWeightingStatement: This sole-authored academic monograph of 173 pages offers extended analysis of children’s childhoods in a digital age and implications for creative educational provision.  It includes empirical research data from my previous decade of Possibility Thinking research and key researchers in USA and UK (approximately 400 references) exploring theoretical positions and perspectives drawing on an extensive international literature.  It offers a unique account of childhoods with reference to creativity and digital technologies. Implications for learning are now being explored in European study C2Learn.  This text involved ‘exceptional research effort’ (Main Panel C criterion) synthesizing a wide literature and generating original perspectives

Title: Dialogic: Education for the Internet Age
DoubleWeightingStatement: This book presents a new dialogic theory of the nature and role of education for the Internet Age. It reports findings from two large recent international projects, Science Education for Diversity (1m€) and Metafora (2m€). It also offers a re-evaluation of data from previous UK classroom talk projects going back 20 years. It contains a substantial literature review of dialogic education with technology engaging with over 500 references. Reviews so far have been positive about its contribution to the field. The book, which is 80,000 words long, was written over a one year period including 6 months dedicated study leave.

Title: Metacognition in Young Children
DoubleWeightingStatement: This 185 page sole authored academic book (80,000 words, 4 pages of index, over 200 references) is unique in synthesizing research on metacognition across a wide range of curriculum areas.  Theories of metacognition are critically analysed with reference to developments in cognitive neuroscience; embodied cognition, mindfulness and transpersonal psychology. The book draws on ten years of the author’s own research including a three year project on metacognition during a cognitive acceleration programme and a one year project on young children’s writing and metacognition. The book argues for a theory of metacognition which takes account of wider social and political factors.

Title: Addressing tensions and dilemmas in inclusive education
DoubleWeightingStatement: This book presents a contemporary and critical analysis and synthesis from different disciplinary perspectives on the field of inclusive education. It draws on about 400 references in relation to identification and classification of special educational needs and disability, current national and international conceptions of disability and learning difficulties in education, pedagogic and curriculum issues, schooling, parental and student perspectives and philosophical and research positions. This book of 80,000 words was written over a 2-3 year period. It integrates 13 of the authors’ academic publications and relates to 5 distinct research projects over two decades into a novel synthesis.
