Enter the discourse: exploring the discursive roots of inclusivity in mixed-sex martial arts
VolumeTitle: Sport in Society: Cultures, Commerce, Media, Politics
AdditionalInformation: This paper, selected for a special edition of Sport in Society: Cultures, Commerce, Media, Politics on issues pertaining to inclusion, equity and diversity in sport, aims to develop the nascent literature on co-educational sport settings by analysing the features of martial arts training cultures which facilitate practitioners’ acceptance of sex integration. Exploring the mediated framing, gendered marketing strategies, and pedagogical trends typical among many martial arts disciplines, the paper advocates further exploration of factors underpinning the acceptance of sex integration in other sports training cultures which is, as yet, missing from the literature.

Title: 'When you see a normal person …': social class and friendship networks among teenage students
VolumeTitle: British Journal of Sociology of Education
AdditionalInformation: This paper is based on research that adopts an original methodological approach in that it combines socio-graphs and in-depth interviews (n=75) with teenage students. The findings of this paper are significant as they highlight the crucial way in which class inequalities shape the social networks of young people. This study is the first one in the UK to explore this issue drawing on a non-adult population and serves well in providing empirical evidence of the complex yet important influence that class exerts on young people’s attitudes and in turn on their social lives.

Title: Direct, indirect and relational: social class manifestations in teenage students’ accounts
AdditionalInformation: This is an invited paper at the special issue of the Youth and Policy journal. This research employed in-depth interviews and socio-graphs with teenage students (n=75). This methodological approach is original as socio-graphs have not been previously used in relation to this type of research. This paper draws on Bourdieuian frameworks in order to examine the way students understand social class as a concept and make sense of it with regard to their own experiences. The employment of these theoretical frameworks is significant in that it allows for the multiplicity and complexity of class understandings to be exposed and analysed.

Title: Which way to Poland? Re-emerging from romantic unity
VolumeTitle: Reinventing Poland: Economic and Political Transformation and Evolving National Identity
AdditionalInformation: The case study for the chapter is the nationalist youth organisation All-Poland Youth set up in 1922, infamous for its militant anti-Semitism, reactivated in 1989. Unlike other commentators, Sidorenko does not see APY as insignificant but draws attention to cultural continuities which become potent during the period of rapid social change. Drawing on concepts from complexity theory, Sidorenko considers the discourse of patriotism deployed by APY’s political activism as a powerful path dependency which re-mobilizes residual populist processes in emerging social contexts. These are essential to the understanding of the interface between the dynamics of education and identity formation.

Title: On the edge of chaos: Inner city schools and the unequal burden of uncertainty
VolumeTitle: Trust in Education: Truths and Values
AdditionalInformation: This paper, examines the phenomenon of disorder in English schools as symptomatic of major systemic contradictions. It sees disorder as a form of resistance; a complex issue which needs a new paradigm for educational sociology engaging with contemporary developmental psychology. Sidorenko draws on constructivist developmentalism of Robert Kegan and complexity theory and argues for a new ecological approach. She argues that post /structuralist analyses fail to capture the dynamic aspects of educational processes or the role of agency in constructing disorder and failure. The new ecological paradigm offers fresh insights into the relationship between social class and educational under/privilege.

Title: The ecology of education: A social and psychological approach to inequality
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Cross-Disciplinary Subjects in Education (IJCDSE)
AdditionalInformation: The starting point for this theoretical paper is the engagement with the issue of persistent patterned educational inequalities. Whilst taking up the issue of class this discussion argues for an opening up of the field of sociology (of education) to the interdisciplinarity of a complexity perspective approach which re-conceptualizes the school as a social ecology. Sidorenko proposes that an examination of developmental and psychological issues of learners need to inform sociological analyses in order to avoid reductivism of structuralist and post-structuralist accounts of inequality and to develop a nuanced complex approach based on both social and psychological methodologies.

Title: Identity, youth and post-modern social landscapes
AdditionalInformation: Contemporary society celebrates ideas of change, flexibility and self-reliance. These attitudes form part of a landscape of expectations of contemporary adulthood. Is there a class dimension to growing up with uncertainty? This paper draws on the constructivist developmental psychologist Robert Kegan to demonstrate a link between post-modern celebration of liberation of the subject and a neo-liberal neglect of the needs of the young. Sidorenko proposes a bridge between sociological characterisation of contemporary society and a focus on psychological processes involved in adolescence in to create a theoretically sound rationale for political interventions into the lives of the young.

Title: The crisis in higher education: The views of academic professionals on policy, leadership values and operational practices
AdditionalInformation: Responses to a web-based survey, conducted through the HE Academy, show the stratified nature of HEIs as organisations, with senior managers distant from operational realities. Staff frustrations with bureaucratised processes are evidenced, as is disengagement: from academic ‘citizenship’; identification with their institution and alignment with strategy developed within New Public Management approaches. The survey combined views on personal values and espoused and operational values of the system and institutions, Likert ratings of statements on key issues and vignettes of critical incidents. The survey results received wide press coverage, and a Select Committee called the project report in evidence.

Title: Research quality assessment: Objectives, approaches, responses and consequences
AdditionalInformation: This chapter has two main elements. First, a critical comparative review of RQA practices around the world demonstrates a lack of consensus about objectives, processes and criteria – and a lack of alignment between means and ends. The impact of such ambiguity and inconsistency is examined in a UK context using data from a web-based survey of 280 academics and an email enquiry of a small sample of social scientists with a research publication record. The game-playing responses  identified provide evidence of a need for a more open process with clearer objectives and criteria.

Title: The new decade: A watershed in UK higher education?
AdditionalInformation: This paper analyses patterns of applications, student behaviour, and performance, framed by the 2010 DBIS White Paper. It interrogates shifts in the market, and issues of equity and social mobility, drawing statistics from a range of published sources – ‘unknown knowns’. From an LFHE funded project, interviews with current and former senior university staff help identify the challenges for management and responses already evident in moves to corporate enterprise approaches. This is a first publication to identify these significant shifts and their implications for a stratified system and strategic funding, and the need for further cultural change in institutional management.

Title: Research assessment: Work in progress, or 'la lutta continua'
VolumeTitle: Reconceptualising Evaluation in Higher Education: The Practice Turn
AdditionalInformation: This chapter draws on the author’s work over 15 years to present a critical chronology of the UK RAE as it evolves in to the REF. It traces unstated changes in the purpose of the exercise, and its impact on individuals and institutions. Tacit shifts in broader HE policy and the concept of a university and an HE system are identified and interrogated. It concludes that there continue to be contradictions and conflicts between policy-in-principle and policy-in-action which need to be resolved.

Title: Power and resistance in further education: Findings from a study of first-tier managers
AdditionalInformation: Rigour: The research design was triangulated and consisted of semi-structured interviews, observations, documentary analysis and online surveys. In addition, respondent validation was employed which consisted of sending a summary of the findings to the participants and requesting feedback; the accuracy of the findings were confirmed. Data analysis adopted a grounded theory approach consisting of open coding, then axial coding before selective coding took place.

Title: Teacher misbehaviour: An analysis of disciplinary orders by the General Teaching Council for England
AdditionalInformation: The cases analysed were the first 300 that were published between the dates of the research. Cases of registered teachers who were disciplined but not working in schools at the time were omitted as were those few cases of teachers in Further Education colleges.  This achieved consistency in the sample focusing only on primary, secondary and special school sectors. This paper is the first of its kind to analyse GTCE teacher misbehaviour data and begins an important area of future enquiry in the area of teacher professionalism.

Title: The abolition of the General Teaching Council for England and the future of teacher discipline
AdditionalInformation: This publication analyses the policy context of the work on teacher misbehaviour and frames its consideration within the changes to the national regulation of teachers. Building on the previous article, it begins to examine the implications of teacher discipline for the notion of teacher professionalism, in particular the move from regarding teachers as occupational professionals to organisational professionals.

Title:
Recruitment and transition of construction lecturers
in Further Education: The perspective of middle managers
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study that has focused solely on construction middle managers within Further Education and makes a significant contribution to the under researched area of career transitions into FE by using the sociological framework of masculinities to examine the management of transitions. As a result of this work, I am currently in negotiations to speak at the British Association of Construction Heads 2013 conference to present the findings of this research and to further develop this research agenda in collaboration with the Association.

Title: Trust and leadership in post-compulsory education: Some snapshots of displaced dissent
AdditionalInformation: Jameson won the 2011 Chartered Management Institute Award for Leadership and Management Achievement and was shortlisted for the CMI Outstanding Leadership Award, based on insights from her three University of Lancaster/ CEL funded research projects, including Trust and Leadership research reported in this paper. The article considers issues of trust, power and displaced dissent in post-compulsory education, providing snapshots of participant views recorded in 28 interviews and 242 electronic survey responses in 2004-09. The theme of the DPR9 Trust conference at Greenwich, involving 130 participants from 33 countries, emerged from the research conference presentation and DPR9 book chapter on Trust.

Title: 'Nothing will prevent me from doing a good job'. The professionalisation of part-time teaching staff in further and adult education
AdditionalInformation: Recognised by the University and College Union in an invited Keynote presentation at the UCU Anti-Casualisation campaign November 2009 launch, the research reported in this paper reflected on findings from two reports by the authors from Learning and Skills Development Agency-funded research (2002-06) involving 700 part-time staff in the lifelong learning sector, surveyed regionally in a collaborative action research process. The authors overturn simplified assumptions about part-timeness, advocating enhanced professionalisation for part-time staff and inclusion in policy change agendas. Although marginalised and largely unsupported, part-time staff make creative use of professional autonomy and agency to mitigate problematic 'casual employment' conditions.

Title: Leadership values, trust and negative capability: Managing the uncertainties of future English Higher Education
AdditionalInformation: This invited paper for a special HEQ journal edition on English higher education following Jameson’s and Huisman’s SRHE 2011 presentations, is the first of its kind to explore Keats’s metaphor of ‘negative capability’ to investigate university leadership during HE policy and fee uncertainties. Data from university experts, managers and academics at elite and mass universities in cross-UK semi-structured interviews were informed by and triangulated against findings from questionnaires (n=16), surveys (n=121) and a focus group (n=6) using thematic analysis of emergent codes. This paper summarises perspectives analysed in-depth in the funded Leadership Foundation report and invited Oxford University Public Lecture.

Title: Distributed leadership and the visibility/invisibility paradox in on-line communities
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study in which a paradox of leadership visibility/invisibility is investigated regarding distributed leadership in online communities. Data collected from three communities were analysed using a pattern-matching process, from which a paradoxical relationship between leadership visibility/invisibility emerged in mixed methods conversational analysis of asynchronous interaction in online polylogues, contributing to contemporary global insights into e-leadership. The research led to a special e-Leadership edition of the British Journal of Educational Technology (2013), with Jameson as main guest editor, and Jameson’s invited speech alongside Prof Diana Laurillard at the Wiley-BJET BERA 2012 seminar Redefining the Field of Educational Technology.

Title: Assuring quality in transnational higher education: A matter of collaboration or control?
AdditionalInformation: This article offers an original contribution to research into transnational higher education; it compares three codes of practice for the assurance of quality from the three main exporters of higher education (USA, UK and Australia). The research was conducted within a textually-orientated critical discourse analysis framework, and draws on tools from linguistics to reveal the unequal power relations between collaborative partners in transnational education and assesses the impact such asymmetrical  relationships can have on understandings of equivalence and adaptation. The article provides a novel proposal for collaborative globalised curriculum development based on postcolonial studies’ notion of the ‘contact zone’.

Title: Exploring flying faculty teaching experiences: Motivations, challenges and opportunities
AdditionalInformation: This research was funded by prize money from the Society for Research into Higher Education Newer Researcher Prize in 2009. It used the Biographical Narrative Interpretative Method (BNIM) for both data collection and analysis; BNIM has not been frequently used in higher education research. Data was collected through three interviews with each participant; the very open structure empowered interviewees to share their own stories. Analysis involved in-depth individual and panel-based processes, exploring biography chronology, discourse and recurrent themes. The research provided insight into flying faculty teachers’ experiences; an area which has received scant research attention by UK academics.

Title: Race relations legislation, ethnicity and disproportionality in school exclusions in England
AdditionalInformation: This article extends the analysis and commentary on the two year DCSF-funded study, Minority Ethnic Exclusions and the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000, Research Report 616, www.dfes.gov.uk/research/data /uploadfiles/RR616.pdf. The research was based on visits to 80 schools sampled across 12 local authorities, set within a context of two years of PLASC (Pupil Level Annual School Census) data. The analysis showed that even taking account of other contextual data, the disproportionality of minority ethnic exclusions from school was reduced by only one third. Only one third of schools studied were fully compliant with the Race Relations legislation.

Title: Explaining sustained inequalities in ethnic minority school exclusions in England—passive racism in a neoliberal grip
AdditionalInformation: This article extends the theorising in the Minority Ethnic Exclusions and the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000, research, questioning the utility of the notion of ‘institutional racism’. It proposes the concept of ‘passive racism’, which has three levels of severity. It postulates that the application of this concept would have greater leverage in generating preventative action in schools, local authorities and the education establishment in addressing the recurrent, routine and damaging inequality in ethnic minority school exclusions.

Title: Achieving zero permanent exclusions from school, social justice and economy
AdditionalInformation: Known for his sustained engagement with DCSF/DfE exclusion monitoring data and policy on school exclusions, Parsons extends his argument in Strategic Alternatives to Exclusion from School project (Trentham Press, 2010) that zero exclusions are possible. A national conference and four regional workshops were run and the author was invited to give evidence to government select committees and the Children’s Commissioner and, subsequently on steering groups for the exclusions research for both. He is invited to address local and national conferences on how committed local authorities with their communities can successfully make permanent exclusions redundant.

Title: Challenged school – challenged society: stacking the odds against the poor
AdditionalInformation: Using the research from the author’s Schooling the Estate Kids (Sense Publishers, 2012) together with local, national and international quantitative data the argument is developed that areas of poverty are made and sustained by national and local policy. Reviews have been positive and the work is contributing to the case against sustained inequalities put by authors in Britain, Europe and America arguing that Education is not effectively countering or able to counter other forces which inhibit social mobility and reduced life chances for the poorest children

Title: After Beslan: Childhood, complexity and risk
AdditionalInformation: This paper considers Beslan as a crisis point at which the postmodern celebration of difference spills into unbearable chaos. However this turns out to show dynamic, self -organising characteristics. Central to these interactions is the formation, however loose or opportunistic, of micro-identities that also produce  outgroups open to  deconstruction or  loss of rights and abuse. At Beslan this reaches a crisis, both localised and universally challenging: it poses the problem of intolerability for a democratic community premised on pluralistic tolerance. The impact is a radical realignment of the sociology (of childhood) along the axes of human ecology and constrained possibility.

Title: Modelling education systems: An ecological approach
VolumeTitle: International Journal for Cross-Disciplinary Subjects in Education (IJCDSE)
AdditionalInformation: This paper aims to outline concepts essential to the idea of the ecologies of education systems. The principle of self-organisation in sociology is reformulated as eco-auto-organisation. Similarly self-reference in the social construction of meaning is reconceptualised as auto-exo-reference. This transforms the notion of social construction from autonomy and conventionality with the requirement of ecological robustness.  Similarly where sociology emphasises human uniqueness and autonomy, perspectives derived from evolutionary psychology offer the more modest concept of relative post-natal plasticity. The impact for the sociology of education is radical: preconscious dispositions, emotion  and embodiment pay a role as important as conscious intentionality.

Title: The construction of childhood, learning and play: an evolutionary and ecological revision
AdditionalInformation: This paper questions the causal adequacy of the ‘social’ construction of childhood arguing that it can only be true to a degree. Smith draws on extensive reading from evolutionary psychology in humans and the biosphere to consider the evolutionary paradox, that play seems an excess, especially in the prolonged childhood of humans. Given that play is demonstrably an ecologically robust strategy in many species, it is argued that the concept of excess is a misunderstanding. Detailed analysis of the role of play in development, the evolution of intelligence, parallel processing and expert routines and its centrality to social interaction follows.

Title: Reshaping social theory from complexity and ecological perspectives
AdditionalInformation: This paper argues for a most radical reshaping of social theory , exploring the consilience between sociology, socio-biology, evolutionary psychology, the philosophy of biology and ecology and their links with pragmatic philosophy. Without this, sociology practises a methodical isolationism, not enriched by contemporary sciences, nor even evolutionary paradigms. It draws on material from a number of sciences, including thermodynamics, complexity theory, cognitive biology, theory of the emotions and in particular, relationships between the social and the biosphere. Since social theory is a key disciplines for education studies, this has impact on all its aspects, from learning process to behavioural repertoires.

Title: Education and climate change - some systemic connections
VolumeTitle: British Journal of Sociology of Education
AdditionalInformation: Ainley’s original analysis of education as a system that is fundamentally unsustainable is presented in an article critiquing the organisation and purposes of education and training, notably of UK ‘learning’. Ainley contends that in a new market?state formation the pursuit of short?term goals is tied to the global free?market economy over which attempts at democratic control have been relinquished. Since humanity worldwide faces increasing ecological change, this educational approach is ‘ecocidally insane’, the opposite of learning from experience to alter future behaviour. The re?regulated new global market is an unsustainable response to the end of the Keynesian welfare nation?state formation.

Title: Lost Generation? New strategies for youth and education
AdditionalInformation: Book examining schools and colleges in the broader economic and employment context related to the position of youth. An informed commentary and critique based on research. Originality - a readable pulling together of education policies post 14/16, mainly New Labour, but also examines earlier policies. Last chapter picks up on Gove. Rigour - based on 20 or so years of work in the field, sharp policy analyses and deep knowledge of large and small scale studies. Aimed at a wide readership, Ainley’s own work is drawn on heavily. Significance - a useful capturing of moves within a recent policy landscape.

Title: Education and the reconstitution of social class in England
AdditionalInformation: This paper extends Gamble 2009 in seeing a reconstitution of the reserve army of labour as a key function of capitalist crisis but education and training are deeply implicated in a wider class reformation, not only relegating an unskilled section of the previously manually working class to worthless vocational certification but also cramming for academic qualifications to ‘restart social mobility’. Efforts to ‘educate our way out of economic crisis’ are questioned since there is no ‘new correspondence’ between education and economy. Education must therefore regain its purpose of critically learning from the past to meet the crisis of the present.

Title: Why young people can't get the jobs they want and what can be done about it
AdditionalInformation: This article brings together in accessible form for a wide audience, an updating of my previous book with Martin Allen 'Lost Generation?' to include the latest Coalition policies for education and youth

Title: Ground rules for talk: The acceptable face of prescription
AdditionalInformation: This paper contributes to the scholarly research on structured talk strategies in the primary classroom - known as ‘ground rules for talk’ (Mercer 2000). Its significance and international reach are shown through citations by Mercer, Simpson and Majors (2010) as being exemplary of an argument which critiques their position. It also develops a fuller conceptual framework for research on this topic, embedding the significance of cultures, social class and power.

Title: Class consciousness, power, identity, and the motivation to teach
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the first of its kind to draw on classic Marxist class theory to analyse a set of narratives of contemporary primary school student teachers in the UK to ascertain the ways in which class history and class-consciousness sculpt perceptions and aspirations in teaching.  Eight student teachers were interviewed in depth at intervals during their PGCE course. They were selected on the basis of their perceptions of being or coming from working class families. A thematic analysis of emergent categories was applied to the interview data collected as part of an iterative research process.

Title: Literacy on the left: Reform and revolution
AdditionalInformation: The book studies the ideological sources of educational practice in literacy and explores discourses from the political ‘left’ involved in the teaching of literacy. This is the first book to analyse and critique the nature of left-leaning ideological approaches to the teaching of literacy using a classic Marxist theoretical lens. Lambirth creates an analytical framework with which to examine and categorise perspectives for the teaching of literacy. The originality of the approach to understanding literacy schooling is reflected in the publisher’s decision, due to sales, to provide a second edition in paperback in November 2012.

Title: Film and pedagogy: Learning about teaching at the movies
VolumeTitle: Lights! Camera! Action and the Brain: The Use of Film in Education
AdditionalInformation: This chapter forms part of an international collection of papers. The work was peer reviewed by a prestigious international panel. The chapter presents a case study of an innovative project which encouraged student teachers to learn from commercial films made about schooling and education. The data were collected from virtual learning discussion board entries (n.57), and from field notes made from post-screening discussions (n.10). The chapter offers insights and recommendations on how films about schooling can stimulate learning around important issues amongst student-teachers by extra-curricular provision in ways that many current teacher training programmes in England arguably fail to do

Title: Socialising young literacy learners into a discourse of failure: Dominant discourses in literacy teaching and assessment and their impact on the progression of young literacy learners into employment
VolumeTitle: Occasional Papers in Education & Lifelong Learning
AdditionalInformation: This study focuses on a more defined identification of the causes of the often trumpeted limitations of young people in using literacy in the work place. While many studies have chronicled the tale of woe in terms of young people’s literacy suitability, very little has been done in terms of identifying and understanding  what the actual shortcomings are and what is responsible for them. It is from this pragmatic position  that this study takes a departure by identifying what learners, employers and teachers consider to be the sources of the gaps highlighted.

Title: Beyond locutionary denotations: exploring trust between practitioners and policy
AdditionalInformation: This paper explores one of the sometimes hidden causes of breakdown in trust. It takes an interdisciplinary approach, drawing from the linguistic field of Speech Act to show how a trust relationship can develop between policy and practitioners. The orignality in this research is the exploration of a trust relationship between policy and practitioners which has not really been explored before in this context. Understanding the potential existence of this relationship is advocated as crucial to our understanding of causes and ways to remedy the breakdown of trust.

Title: Practitioners' perception of the impact of the vision of policy-makers on practice: The example of the recommendations of the Moser Commission
AdditionalInformation: This paper is significant in the debate around the policy that informed the design and development of the Skills for Life curriculum. It uses a multi-method approach in data collection and analysis to triangulate its findings.  The timing of the research, immediate post-SFL funding, makes it an original contribution to the debate on 'what next' in literacy development. Its originality also stems from its mapping of practitioners’ views. Finally, the paper is significant because it involves the largest number of the members of the Moser Committee ever reported in a single study.

Title: Practitioners' perceptions of dyslexia and approaches towards teaching learners with dyslexia in adult literacy classes
AdditionalInformation: This paper challenges the assumption that teacher education graduates are ‘ready to teach’ which is often premised on teacher education programmes content rather that the attitudinal readiness of trainee teachers. It argues that exposure to theories of dyslexia does not necessarily prepare trainees for teaching learners with dyslexia and concludes that it is the limited understanding of dyslexia that renders trainees unprepared for teaching learners with dyslexia. Evidence from the research should alert teacher educators to the limitations to the current structure in terms of preparing trainees for teaching learners with dyslexia.

Dimensions of Expertise : a conceptual exploration of vocational knowledge
DoubleWeightingStatement: ‘Dimensions of Expertise’ is one of very few substantial philosophical book-length treatments available of professional/ vocational knowledge.  Each of its ten chapters covers a topic substantial enough to be considered as a journal article, although the book constitutes an argumentative unity. It engages with current debates within mainstream epistemology concerning claims as to whether know-how is a species of know-that and relates this discussion to substantial issues in vocational and professional education concerning the nature of curricula and qualifications. It also critically examines currently influential theories of expertise such as those of Dreyfus and Dreyfus and Bereiter and Scardamalia.

Understanding Education : a sociological perspective
AdditionalInformation:
Material in common with outputs published prior to 2008:
As noted in the acknowledgements, parts of this book draw on work that was originally published in academic journals prior to 2008, but this material has been substantially developed and reworked, and combined with new material, a) to construct an entirely new argument about the importance of recognizing and celebrating the normative dimension of the sociology of education, and b) to strengthen and extend arguments developed in previous work for a more ethically reflexive and policy-oriented sociology. In total, the previously published material comprises approximately 15% of the book, with the other 85% comprised of wholly new material.

Additional factual information about the significance of the output:
Greek translation by Eleanna Panagou, Athens: Metaichmio, 2011. Serbian translation by Slobodanka Glisic, Belgrade: Fabrika knjiga, 2012.

Title: How Schools do Policy : Policy Enactments in Secondary Schools
Review of vocational education : the Wolf report
AdditionalInformation:
The Wolf Review was commissioned from Professor Alison Wolf by the government with the following brief:

To consider how we can improve vocational education for 14-19 year olds and thereby promote successful progression into the labour market and into higher level education and training routes.

The research for the review addressed a series of questions detailed in the report which underlie the policy recommendations. As part of the review, a formal public consultation was carried out. This centred on a number of the research questions and respondents were asked for relevant empirical evidence and publications as well as analysis and recommendations.  A series of meetings were held with experts in the field, including though not confined to leading academics in the vocational education and training field. These also addressed the research questions.  Study visits were paid to Denmark and France and additional statistical and financial data obtained from relevant ministries. 

The methods by which the research questions were addressed were 
•	A systematic search of government department databases and reports to identify relevant documents from 1985 onwards, including programme evaluations
•	A systematic search of national and international databases for relevant policy literature, curriculum documents, evaluations and peer-reviewed articles
•	Analysis of outputs of consultations and study visits, including both direct responses and identified material/data
•	Statistical analysis of major datasets, including Labour Force Survey, British Household Panel Survey, National Child Development Study, Longitudinal Study of Young People in England, Youth Cohort Study
•	Statistical analysis of government administrative data, including data on funding, qualifications, apprenticeship starts, made available by DfE, YPLA , NAS, UKCES

All material and statistical analyses were reviewed for accuracy prior to publication by government statistical analysts and selected expert reviewers.  Following publication, the research was presented to expert academic audiences, parliamentary committees and national conferences.

Publisher: Centre for Language, Discourse & Communication, King's College London
AdditionalInformation:
These professional development materials draw on two ESRC projects (see pp.v-vi): “Urban Classroom Culture & Interaction”, 2005-2008 (Identities & Social Action Programme) (= UCCI:1); “Urban Classroom Culture & Interaction 2: From Research to Professional Practice” 2009-2011 (Follow-on Funding) (= UCCI:2).  The 4 focal interactional episodes and their contextualisation draw on UCCI:1’s ethnographic & radio-mic data-collection.  The pedagogic method and the substantive issues that the materials address were developed and refined through:
•         7 x 2-2½ hours workshops focused on interactional data with 39 experienced urban secondary school-teachers (all audio-recorded & transcribed with NVivo), supplemented with a brief questionnaire (UCCI:1, 2007)
•         a series of seminars with 39 experienced urban secondary teachers – 3 sessions each with two groups (15hrs), and 9 hours with 2 MA groups (all audio-recorded & NVivo transcribed; UCCI:2, 2009-10)
•         post-seminar written comments from each UCCI:2 participant, and conversational interviews with three of the most experienced (1½-2 hours each – all recorded & NVivo transcribed; UCCI:2).
In all, the PD materials draw on >45hrs of recordings with 78 urban teachers whose combined professional experience totals 973 years.

Is the UK an outlier? : An international comparison of upper secondary mathematics education
AdditionalInformation:
This research report addresses a set of research questions that are listed in the report. The report is based on an analysis of evidence in 24 country profiles, published as a separate addendum: Hodgen, J. et al. (2010). An international comparison of upper secondary mathematics education: 24 country profiles. London: The Nuffield Foundation, available at: http://www.nuffieldfoundation.org/sites/default/files/files/Country_profiles_outlier_NuffieldFoundation18_04_11.pdf
The method, described in detail in the addendum, was as follows. The research team conducted a systematic online search to identify policy literature, national data and curricula documents. This search used international databases (e.g., INCA, Eurydice) together with Ministry of Education websites and those of associated arms-length technical bodies. The search focused on identifying English-language sources, although some translation was carried out where either curricular documents or participation data were not available in English. Country profiles were drafted addressing the study’s research questions, including information on participation rates. For each country, a national contact was identified with detailed knowledge of policy and practice in mathematics education. Their role was to check and comment on this information, and to provide any important supplementary information or sources of evidence. Following several iterations, final country profiles were validated by the national contacts. 
Prior to publication, the report was blind peer-reviewed by academics chosen by the funders, The Nuffield Foundation. The research was funded following competitive tendering. Dissemination included invited seminars, media coverage, a ministerial meeting and briefings for key policy-makers. The report has been cited as the key evidence in 4 influential reports on post-16 mathematics (e.g., Advisory Committee on Mathematics Education, The Conservative Party’s Mathematics Taskforce) and 6 ministerial speeches on mathematics education indicating a change in government policy towards ensuring “that within a decade the vast majority of pupils [should be] studying maths right through to the age of 18” (Michael Gove, 29/6/2011).

Title: Knowing and identity: A situated theory of mathematics knowledge in teaching
Values and variables : mathematics education in high-performing countries
AdditionalInformation:
This research report addresses research questions listed in the report. 
This report is a review and synthesis of the mathematics education literature relating to countries that attained highly on the mathematics strand of TIMSS 2003. The literature was identified by electronic searches of online databases (e.g., Web of Science, MathEduc) together with web searches of the ‘grey’ literature not published in peer-reviewed journals (via search engines and Ministry of Education and related websites). Initially, 1600 items were identified as potentially relevant, and graded (1, 2 or 3) on the basis of relevance and methodological rigour, using criteria drawn from Slavin (1986) and Meade (2000). A total of 550 items were graded 1. These items were categorised in two ways: (i) by country and (ii) using a set of nested layers that we developed during the scoping exercise. The “top-level” layers were as follows: National / Societal, Schooling System, Curriculum Support, Classroom Practices, Pupils. Within each of these layers, nested sub-layers were identified. In Curriculum support, for example, these sub-layers included Instruction manuals, Advisory/inspection systems, Textbooks, ICT, and Pedagogy/didactics. During the process of analysis and synthesis of the literature, national experts in mathematics education were asked to comment on any surprising or unexpected claims in order to place these in the wider socio-cultural context.
Prior to publication, the report was blind peer-reviewed by academics with expertise in comparative education chosen by the Nuffield Foundation, who funded the study. The research was funded following a competitive tendering process. 
Dissemination included three invited seminars for policy-makers, dissemination through the National Centre for Excellence in Teaching Mathematics, several seminars for teachers, advisers and the Joint Mathematical Council, a Ministerial Round Table (Nick Gibb, then Schools Minister, 2010), and invited advice to the Department for Education and to the National Curriculum Review / writing team.

DoubleWeightingStatement: The Development of Higher Education in the United Kingdom since 1945 is the only comprehensive, single-volume, up-to-date and critical assessment available of the post-war history of UK higher education. An informed understanding of the major changes that have taken place during this period is of crucial importance in appreciating where UK higher education is now, and hence how it might further develop. The book is firmly based on an interrogation of the research and policy literature produced over several decades, offering a clear and thematic overview of the major developments.

DoubleWeightingStatement: Qualitative longitudinal research is rare on the temporal scale demonstrated in this book. The study demanded persistence and commitment over a fourteen year period of data collection. The analytic task was complex requiring longitudinal analysis, cross sectional analysis and a drawing together of the two with an unwavering theoretical   focus on identity change through childhood and adolescence. The resulting presentation of case studies provides a nuanced and significant contribution to our understanding of the ways that self is created and recreated over time. The duration, complexity and detail of this unusual qualitative longitudinal study warrant a double weighting.
