Introduction: Learning about diversity
AdditionalInformation: This chapter presents a theoretical rationale for using a particular approach to school-based research in the field of inclusive education. Miles was co-Investigator for 12 small-scale studies presented in this book, on which this theorisation is based.

Title: Beyond 'emotional literacy' in feminist and educational research
Children's social and emotional wellbeing in schools
Conduct problems prevention research group. The effects of the Fast Track Preventive Intervention on the development of conduct disorder across Childhood.
Measures of Social and Emotional Skills for Children and Young People A Systematic Review
The shadows of difference: ethnicity and young children’s friendships
AdditionalInformation: REE is the official journal of the relevant Special Interest Groups (SIGS) of the American Educational Research Association (AERA) and the British Educational Research Association (BERA); the leading journal on racism and race inequality in education.

Title: Finding a voice: A figured worlds approach to theorising young children's identities
AdditionalInformation: Develops an innovative approach to understanding identity and ethnicity in young children, drawing on sociocultural, critical race theory and the potential of the ‘figured worlds’ literature. The journal supports theoretically informed interdisciplinary research in early childhood.

Title: The potential and challenges of critical realist ethnography
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Research & Method in Education
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading journal on research methodology in educational research; an innovative critique and application of critical realist theory in ethnographic research in the early years

Title: Performing Child(hood)
AdditionalInformation: Journal of the National Children’s Bureau; an international, interdisciplinary journal publishing high quality research and debate on all aspects of childhood and policies and services for children and young people

Title: Limitless provocations of the ‘safe’, ‘secure’ and ‘healthy’ child
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Qualitative Studies in Education
AdditionalInformation: Draws on art theory to interrupt stereotypical and utopian visions of ‘the child’. Dealing with highly sensitive imagery in an ethically serious manner, the article opens up questions about how children are conceptualized in education policy and practice. Based on methodological innovations in film and visual representations developed during ESRC RES-189-25-0122.

Title: Reflexivity as a Ground-Clearing Activity Within the Context of Early Years' Pedagogy
AdditionalInformation: Published in internationally leading journal edited from USA, the paper draws on an ESRC ethnographic study (RES–062-23-0105) and critically interrogates the pursuit of emancipatory practices in early years education.

Title: Children and objects: affection and infection
VolumeTitle: Early Years International Journal of Research
AdditionalInformation: Based on ESRC (RES–062-23-0105) the article develops methodological and substantive insights through attention to the significance of objects in the early years classroom. It led to an invitation to give the Erskine Scholar Prestige lecture, University of Christchurch, New Zealand, 2011. Version of the paper were also presented at the University of Oulu, Finland (2012), Oslo University College of Applied Sciences, Norway (2013) and the British Educational Research Association Conference (2012).

Title: Can Liberal Education Make a Comeback? The Case of "Relational Touch" at Summerhill School
AdditionalInformation: Jointly written paper emerging from ESRC RES-000-22-0815 (rated ‘outstanding’), the article makes a significant intervention into debates over alternative education. Published in one of the leading educational research journals worldwide (ranked 3/216 in ISI Education and Educational Research).

Title: Child abuse, child protection, and defensive ‘touch’ in PE teaching and sports coaching
AdditionalInformation: Based on an ESRC project on touch in sports education (ESRC RES-000-22-41562) which developed from Piper's previous research on the problematics of touch in schools (RES-000-22-0815). The paper significantly extends theorising of the topic beyond concepts of moral panic into the domain of governmentality and moral regulation.

Title: Becoming a problem: behaviour and reputation in the early years classroom
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading UK journal, the paper  comprises a substantive report and critical discussion of the findings of an ESRC-funded ethnographic study of the emergence of challenging behaviour in the early years at school (RES–062-23-0105).

Title: What are multimodal data and transcription?
AdditionalInformation: International Handbook representing leading edge research in multi-modal analysis. The chapter critically reviews emergent transcription methodologies and their representational and epistemological implications for educational research, drawing on empirical materials including excerpts from Lancaster’s ESRC-funded multi-modal research in early mark-making (RES-000-22-0599).

Title: The dragon in the cave: textual representations of fictional and every day events by children under three
AdditionalInformation: Based on ESRC research into early graphic representation (RES-000-22-0599), the chapter developed from an invited presentation to an international conference, University of Cologne 2009, and the paper was selected for inclusion in the resulting volume of articles. A second volume is to be published by Routledge in 2014, to which the author has been asked to contribute.

Title: The Emergence of Symbolic Principles: The Distribution of Mind in Early Sign Making
AdditionalInformation: Published online 03 October 2013, in international journal edited from Italy and USA; the journal provides a platform for exceptional peer-reviewed papers which span biology, philosophy, linguistics and the communication sciences. The paper derives from ESRC project (RES-000-22-0599); it is based on a presentation to the National Reading Conference, USA 2010.This extended version was accepted as a contribution to two multi-disciplinary special issues on the ‘origin of mind’.

Title: The professionalisation of sports coaching: relations of power, resistance and compliance
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading journal in the field; one of the first articles to use empirical, field-based data in research on the professionalization of sport coaching in the UK. It develops an analysis based on Foucault and Bourdieu to problematize one-to-one educational practices previously treated as procedural and unproblematic. The article is 5th in the journal’s most downloaded list. The paper was presented at the International Congress of Qualitative Inquiry 2009 and BERA Annual Conference 2010.

Title: Sports coaching in risk society: No touch! No trust!
AdditionalInformation: Analyses pilot data which led to an ESRC grant (ESRC RES-000-22-41562) to research the politics of touch in sports coaching. Develops a theoretically and empirically grounded approach to ethical practice in a highly sensitive area

Title: 'Safeguarding sports' coaching: Foucault, genealogy and critique
AdditionalInformation: Draws on data from the ESRC ‘touch’ project (RES-000-22-41562) to develops a Foucauldian critique of prevailing discourses relating to child abuse in sport coaching. Generates highly significant implications for child protection policy and practice.

Title: Don't Touch!: The Educational Story of a Panic
AdditionalInformation: Output resulted from ESRC RES-000-22-0815 (rated ‘outstanding’). Piper was solely or predominantly responsible for chapters 1, 3, 6 & 11. There is clear evidence of impact on policy: Importance of Teaching White Paper 2010, endnote 43 and REF3b. The book prompted numerous national and international conference presentations. “This is a very important ... attempt to provide answers to the question ... why have we become so anxious about intergenerational physical contact?...every teacher needs to engage with the issues raised in Don’t Touch.” Frank Furedi, University of Kent, British Journal of Educational Studies, 2009, 57 (4).

Title: Becoming Child/Becoming Dress
AdditionalInformation: Based on ESRC research (RES–062-23-0105), the article is published in a special issue on the international significance of the work of Deleuze and Guattari for research and practice in early childhood. The paper led to invitations to present a keynote session to BERA Early Childhood SIG conference 2013 and a Master Class at Oslo University College of Applies Sciences, Norway (25.06.13).

Title: Children's Encounters With Things: Schooling the Body
AdditionalInformation: Published in internationally leading journal edited from USA; draws on ESRC project (RES–062-23-0105). Versions of the paper were presented to: video symposium with Deakin University, Australia 2011; seminar at Charles Sturt University, Australia 2012.

Title: Opening It All Up
AdditionalInformation: The article explores the use of micro-multimodal analysis to investigate cognitive process in early mark-making, based on the approach pioneered in ESRC project (RES-000-22-0599). The article derives from an invited paper to the conference, ‘Enriching Early Childhood Literacy Curricula and Practice’, University of Lancaster 2012.

Title: What's Wrong with Democracy at the Moment, and Why It Matters for Research and Education
AdditionalInformation: A significant and original critique of the relation between education, research and democracy. Journal of the annual Discourse Power Resistance (DPR) international conference.

Title: Obama and the ‘Arab Spring’: desire, hope and the manufacture of disappointment. Implications for a transformative pedagogy
VolumeTitle: Discourse: Studies in the Cultural Politics of Education
AdditionalInformation: Contribution to special issue in leading international journal edited from Australia; theorises and critiques ‘public pedagogies’ through which the ‘public mind’ is shaped or ‘schooled’ and consent is ‘manufactured’ drawing on a substantial collection of on-line and press data.

Title: Researching Sex and Lies in the Classroom: Allegations of Sexual Misconduct in Schools
AdditionalInformation: An original and independent challenge to dominant discourses in a highly contested field. Piper was mainly responsible for chapters 2, 5 & 6, and jointly responsible for chapters 1, 3 & 10.The work generated numerous national and international conference presentations, and also influenced policy (see House of Commons Children, Schools and Families Committee 2008-2009 and REF3b). The book received an International Congress of Qualitative Inquiry Award (Ilinois 2010).

Title: From interprofessional working to transprofessional possibilities: the new age of sports coaching in the United Kingdom
AdditionalInformation: Examines issues surrounding new professional groups as they struggle to gain a foothold in new occupational fields and negotiate the complex landscape of educational and medical policy in professional and transprofessional contexts. Using Bourdieu’s notion of occupational capital, the paper marks an important intervention  in the field. The paper is the third most accessed paper on line. It was presented as an invited address at the First International Coaching Cultures Conference, Manchester 2011,  launching the new journal

Title: Voices from an edge. Unsettling the practices of youth voice and participation: arts-based practice in The Blue Room, Manchester
AdditionalInformation: Article reporting an evaluation of an informal education ‘streetwork’ project, funded from a Comic Relief grant held by TIPP (Theatre in Prisons) on behalf of The Blue Room 2007-08. The research involved an interview and participant observation study; critically contrasts notions of ‘voice’ in educational research and youth work respectively. The article led to a presentation to British Educational Research Association Conference 2013.

Title: Dangerous spaces, dangerous memories, dangerous emotions: informal education and heteronormativity – a Manchester UK Youth Work vignette
VolumeTitle: Discourse: Studies in the Cultural Politics of Education
AdditionalInformation: Based on presentation to British Educational Research Association Conference 2011. Focuses on issues relating to gay citizenship and informal education arising from an  evaluation of the Blue Room (later Men’s Room) project in Manchester and subsequent unfunded ethnographic research. Original evaluation funded from a Comic Relief grant 2007-08 to the Blue Room.

Title: Youth work, social education, democratic practice and the challenge of difference: A contribution to debate
AdditionalInformation: Draws together research previously presented at Working with Young People Conference, University of Strathclyde, 2011 and British Educational Research Association  Conference 2012. Formulates proposals for youth work practice and informal education based on critical interrogation of social pedagogy and feminist engagements with difference.

Title: ‘Off The Model’: resistant spaces, school disaffection and ‘aspiration’ in a former coal-mining community
‘Sticking together!’ Policy activism from within a UK coal-mining community
VolumeTitle: Journal of Educational Administration and History
AdditionalInformation: Contribution to special issue (ed. J Smyth) on ‘policy activism’. Based on an in-depth ethnographic study, develops an analysis combining cultural geography and psychosocial work on affect. The article led to a Visiting Research Fellowship at the University of Ballarat 2013.

Title: A Practice of Concrete Utopia? Informal Youth Support and the Possibility of 'Redemptive Remembering' in a UK Coal-Mining Area
AdditionalInformation: Contribution to a special issue; based on a doctoral ethnographic study of disaffection in education; a draft of the paper was presented as part of a symposium at the European Conference on Education Research, University of Berlin, 2011. Drawing on Blochian readings of Freire the article calls for a form of intergenerational “redemptive remembering” that I refer to, after Bloch (1995), as a practice of “concrete utopia”.

Title: ‘Blair's children’: young women as ‘aspirational subjects’ in the psychic landscape of class
AdditionalInformation: Published in a leading journal in the discipline; the paper draws on empirical research undertaken in a specialist arts college and work within the Sociology of Education to contribute to theoretical debates around the interpretation and performance of ‘aspiration’. A version of the paper was presented at the BSA annual conference 2011.

Title: Young people's uses of celebrity: class, gender and ‘improper’ celebrity
VolumeTitle: Discourse: Studies in the Cultural Politics of Education
AdditionalInformation: Interdisciplinary study drawing on 3 investigations including Allen’s AHRC-funded doctoral research. Based on presentation to Gender & Education Conference 2011. The article underpinned successful ESRC bid (Allen & Mendick: ES/J022942/1).

Title: 'Sticky Subjects' or 'Cosmopolitan Creatives'? Social Class, Place and Urban Young People's Aspirations for Work in the Knowledge Economy
AdditionalInformation: Published in high-ranking international journal in special issue on youth im/mobilities (eds T. Skelton & K. Gough). The paper explores relationships between place, social class and young people’s educational experiences and career aspirations drawing on research funded by Becta. Presented at the 2012 British Sociological Association international annual conference (education stream).

Title: Becoming employable students and ‘ideal’ creative workers: exclusion and inequality in higher education work placements
VolumeTitle: British Journal of Sociology of Education
AdditionalInformation:
Draws on research funded by the Equality Challenge Unit, has been translated into practical ECU toolkits for HE staff working around employability and equality issues (http://www.ecu.ac.uk/publications/diversity-equality-and-access-toolkits ).Also cited by the Social Mobility Foundation http://www.smf.co.uk/assets/files/SMF%20Disconnected.pdf  and used by the Arts Council 
http://www.artscouncil.org.uk/media/uploads/internships_in_the_arts_final.pdf

Title: Decolonizing researcher authenticity
AdditionalInformation: Significant contribution to postcolonial and decolonizing methodology, based on an HE initiative in Columbia. Published in the leading journal on racism and race inequality in education; official journal of the relevant Special Interest Groups (SIGS) of the American Educational Research Association (AERA) and the British Educational Research Association (BERA).

Title: A promiscuous (feminist) look at grant-science: how colliding imaginaries shape the practice of NSF policy
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Qualitative Studies in Education
AdditionalInformation: Original critique of ‘grant science’ and research funding policy, grounded in an ethnographic study undertaken as part of a USA National Science Foundation project.

Title: Mathematics Education and Subjectivity: cultures and cultural renewal
DoubleWeightingStatement: The book is 216pp, published in Springer’s prestigious Mathematics Education Library series. It derives from a sustained programme of research reconceptualising the nature of mathematics as encountered in educational settings. It incorporates four papers published in period (not returned separately) in the field’s premier journal Educational Studies in Mathematics  (rated A* by the European Society for Research in Mathematics (http://www.mathematik.uni-dortmund.de/~erme/doc/EMS-ERME-Ranking_Journals_Project.pdf). One of these provoked an 8000-word response from the journal’s lead editors (Presmeg & Radford, 2008, 69: 265–276). ESM published a 12000-word review of the book 2012, 80(3), another appeared in ZDM (2013, 44,6)
AdditionalInformation: Requested double weighting: the book is 216pp, published in Springer’s prestigious Mathematics Education Library series. It derives from a sustained programme of research reconceptualising the nature of mathematics as encountered in educational settings. It incorporates four papers published in period (not returned separately) in the field’s premier journal Educational Studies in Mathematics  (rated A* by the European Society for Research in Mathematics (http://www.mathematik.uni-dortmund.de/~erme/doc/EMS-ERME-Ranking_Journals_Project.pdf). One of these provoked an 8000-word response from the journal’s lead editors (Presmeg & Radford, 2008, 69: 265–276). ESM published a 12000-word review of the book 2012, 80(3), another appeared in ZDM (2013, 44,6)

Title: Becoming a Mathematics Teacher: identity and identifications
AdditionalInformation: One of two books published by Brown in Springer’s prestigious Mathematics Education Library (rest of UK =1). Brown is lead author writing 70% of the material. Draws on  two empirical studies funded by the ESRC, originally reported in New teacher identity and regulative government (2005). This new book includes substantial new material throughout and provides a longitudinal account of the National Numeracy Framework from its introduction in 1999 to its conclusion some ten years later. Reviewed positively in Springer’s Educational Studies in Mathematics 2012, 81(1), Journal of Mathematics Teacher Education 2011, 15(2) and Mathematics Education Research Journal, 2012, 23(4).

Title: Subjectivity and cultural adjustment in mathematics education: a response to Wolff-Michael Roth
AdditionalInformation: Invited response to a 12,000 word review of Brown’s work in one of the leading international journals in the field (rated A* by the European Society for Research in Mathematics Education committee (http://www.mathematik.uni-dortmund.de/~erme/doc/EMS-ERME-Ranking_Journals_Project.pdf).  The review and this response  provides definitive evidence of Brown’s world leading contribution to the field.

Title: Institutional Contexts for Research in Mathematics Education
VolumeTitle: Third International Handbook of Mathematics Education
AdditionalInformation: Reserve entry: 13,000 word entry in major international review comprising the leading international authors in the field. Brown was lead author, co-written with Clarke (Director, Melbourne Graduate School of Education).

Title: Experiencing the space we share: rethinking subjectivity and objectivity
AdditionalInformation: ZDM: Zentralblatt fur Didaktik der Mathematik: The international journal on mathematics education. Contribution to Special Issue comprising major authors in the field of teacher education research. Journal rated A in recent European survey (ICMI, EMS, ERME).

Title: Safety in numbers: mathematics support centres and their derivatives as social learning spaces
AdditionalInformation: Based on research data collected as part of Solomon’s funded Visiting Fellow position at SIGMA, Loughborough University and Coventry University Joint Mathematics Education Centre of Excellence; formed the basis of an  invited address to the Mathematics, Statistics and Operational Research Network Conference, Warwick 2010. Draws on research reported in Solomon’s book (2008), but extends and reframes elements of the analysis and  includes reference to a new data set.

Title: Mathematical Literacy: developing identities of inclusion
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading international series, ‘Studies in mathematical thinking and learning’ (ed. Alan Schoenfeld, Berkley).  Subject of a review article in one of the two top-ranked mathematics education journals, Journal for Research in Mathematics Education.  Formed the basis of invited presentation, University of Lisbon, Portugal, 2012.

Title: Dealing with ‘fragile identities’: resistance and refiguring in women mathematics students
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading journal in the field; article derives from Solomon’s funded Visiting Fellow position at SIGMA, Loughborough and Coventry University Joint Mathematics Education Centre of Excellence, and draws on a large data set.

Title: Finding a voice? Narrating the female self in mathematics
AdditionalInformation: Published in foremost international journals on mathematics education research, rated A* by the European Society for Research in Mathematics Education committee. Appears in Special Issue on Mathematics Education and Contemporary Theory. Presented to symposium organized by Professor Anna Sfard (Haifa, Israel), at ISCAR, Rome, 2011. Also presented at an invited talk at Stockholm University, February 2013.

Title: The Pedagogy of Physical Science
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading international series; draws on programme of empirical research published in leading journals including International Journal of Science Education, Cambridge Journal of Education, Journal of Assessment and Evaluation in Higher Education; includes substantial new material throughout including material presented at AERA, BERA, with additional chapters totalling 20,000+  words on the role of language in learning science (chapter 5) and students’ reflecting on their own learning in order to develop pedagogical insight and strategies (chapter 7).

Title: Exploring the Visuospatial Challenge of Learning About Day and Night and the Sun's Path
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading international journal in the field edited from USA (10/219 ISI Education & Educational Research); the article reports a study investigating how pre-service teachers employ models in reasoning about basic astronomy.

Title: Exploring How Engaging With Reflection on Learning Generates Pedagogical Insight in Science Teacher Education
AdditionalInformation: Published in one of the leading journals in the field of edited from the USA (ISI ranking 10/219, for Education & Educational Research).

Title: Criticisms and contradictions of ethnomathematics
AdditionalInformation: Published in the leading journal in the field; derives from two research projects funded by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology. Publications led to the recent invitations to write a chapter for a Norwegian book, an article for a Brazilian journal, and to be a plenary speaker at the Brazilian National Congress on Ethnomathematics 2012.

Title: An ideology critique of the use-value of mathematics
AdditionalInformation: Published in the leading journal in the field; recognised as a particularly significant contribution by the journal since it is published at 12,000 words when the journal’s usual limit is 8,000.  The article derives from two research projects funded by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology; versions of it were presented at congresses in Colombia (2009),  Germany (2010), Denmark 2012).

Title: Researching research: mathematics education in the Political
AdditionalInformation: Published in the leading journal in the field; this output is part of a Special Issue on Contemporary Theory, which gathered some of the most important scholars of the field. It derives from a research project funded by by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology.

Title: Recovering the meaning of ‘critique’ in critical mathematics education
AdditionalInformation: Published in on-line journal, edited from Canada,  rated one of the leading journals of the field by the European Mathematical Society; the article is derived from the project LEARN, funded by the Portuguese Foundation for Science and Technology. Previous versions of this article were presented in international congresses in Germany (2010) and Portugal (2008).

Title: Gaming and the Network Generation
AdditionalInformation: Chapter in an international collection published from the USA; it is one of the earliest critiques of ‘generation theory’, problematizing the concept of the ‘digital native’ and among the first to challenge ideas of ubiquitous motivation in digital games in the context of adult learning. The chapter draws on research undertaken as part of the author’s doctoral work, reporting on the results of two quantitative studies.

Title: Games for Learning
AdditionalInformation: Published in a leading international journal edited from the USA; the article is in a special issue exemplifying research that combines a substantive contribution with methodological reflection; highlights the issues inherent in the proposition that on-line gaming can improve social inclusion. The article draws together research from three different funded projects undertaken by the author  including a large scale JISC initiative and an EU-funded Lifelong Learning multilateral project.

Title: Technology to support parental engagement in elementary education: Lessons learned from the UK
AdditionalInformation: Published in the leading journal in the field, the paper draws on research findings from the national evaluation of BECTA’s ICT Test Bed initiative and the ESRC/EPSRC/DTI Homework project. Published in a special issue highlighting outstanding papers presented to the international Computers and Learning Conference  (CAL) 2009.

Title: Embedding interactive whiteboards in teaching and learning: The process of change in pedagogic practice
AdditionalInformation: Uses mixed methods design to examine the pedagogical impact of interactive whiteboards, based on data from the national evaluation of a BECTA initiative. EIT (Springer) is the official journal of the International Federation of Information Processing (IFIP) technical committee on Education, with links to the UN and UNESCO. Originally presented as a keynote at the IFIP Working Group 3.5 Conference, Prague 2008.

Title: The impact of formal and informal professional development opportunities on primary teachers' adoption of interactive whiteboards
AdditionalInformation: Uses a mixed methods design to investigate use of interactive whiteboards, produces significant implications for practice; based on DfES/BECTA-funded evaluation.

Title: Information and Communication Technologies and the Culture of Schooling: Understanding Innovation and Designing Research for Radical Reform
AdditionalInformation: Australian Journal; the paper develops an original approach to innovation, intervention, and understanding the impact of ICT on schooling, using socio-cultural theory. Based on BECTA/DfES-funded research.

Title: Value(s)-Driven Decision-Making: The Ethics Work of English Headteachers within Discourses of Constraint
AdditionalInformation: Mounts an original challenge to the field of school and academic leadership by exploring tensions between pragmatism and constraint; marks an early contribution to the emerging interest in values-driven behaviours. Based on paper to the British Educational Research Association Annual Conference 2011.

Title: From schools to Higher Education – neoliberal agendas and implications for autonomy
VolumeTitle: Journal of Educational Administration and History
AdditionalInformation: Based on a series of conference presentations British Educational Leadership, Management and Administration Society (BELMAS) 2006; BELMAS 2008; original analysis of shifting trends in HE based on comparison with the effects of neo-liberal shifts in schools.

Title: Chasing improved pupil performance: the impact of policy change on school educators’ perceptions of their professional identity, the case of further change in English schools
AdditionalInformation: Based on Local Authority funded research on workforce remodelling and a paper to the Canadian Association for the Study of Educational Administration Conference (CASEA) Vancouver 2008.

Title: Power, agency and middle leadership in English primary schools
AdditionalInformation: Article draws on research funded by Staffordshire and Warwickshire Local Authorities and research funded by the National College for School Leaders, and is based on papers presented to BELMAS 2008 and BERA 2009.

Title: Pre-service teachers’ shifting perceptions of cross-curricular practice: The impact of school experience in mediating professional insight
AdditionalInformation: Published in special issue on curriculum organisation and approaches to learning. The special issue includes authors from Europe and Australia.

Title: Developing pre-service primary teachers’ perceptions of cross-curricular teaching through reflection on learning
AdditionalInformation: Leading international teacher education journal; the paper reports research on the authors’ pre-service teacher education courses.

Title: Theorising practice in initial teacher education
AdditionalInformation: Published in long-established teacher education journal; reports practitioner research investigating student conceptions of theory; a critical interrogation of the significance of theory in ITE in response to the emergence of employment-based teacher education.

Title: Reasserting theory in professionally based initial teacher education
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading teacher education journal, the paper reviews definitions of theory in the context of  empirical research conducted over the course of two academic years.

Title: Teacher educator changing perceptions of theory
AdditionalInformation: Reports a programme of practitioner research into the significance of theory in teacher education, focusing on the ways in which tutor conceptions of theory adjusted to changes in student perceptions. Parts of the paper were presented in a featured symposium at the Australian Association of Research in Education in Sydney, 2012.

Title: The discursive production of classroom mathematics
AdditionalInformation: Theoretically informed exploration of the discourse of maths in the classroom, for a special issue on language in mathematics education in the principal Australian journal in the field.

Title: Using Assessment to Drive the Reform of Schooling: Time to Stop Pursuing the Chimera?
AdditionalInformation: Based on a keynote address to New Zealand Educational Research Association 2010, and BERA conference paper 2011; substantial, original, significant analysis of UK test results and international debate on using tests to reform schools;

Title: Formative assessment at the crossroads: conformative, deformative and transformative assessment
AdditionalInformation: Based on seminar presentation at Auckland University, December 2010, and BERA paper 2011; original, significant and timely review of key issues and practice in international debate on formative assessment

Title: Qualitative Research, Science and Government: evidence, criteria, policy and politics
VolumeTitle: The SAGE Handbook of Qualitative Research
AdditionalInformation: Chapter published in world leading handbook, edited from USA; based on papers presented to American Educational Research Association conference 2009 and Australian Association for Educational Research conference 2010. Definitive review, analysis and critique of educational research governance and methods, and the relationship between research, policy and practice.

Title: Triangulation, Respondent Validation, and Democratic Participation in Mixed Methods Research
AdditionalInformation: Published in special issue of field-defining international journal, edited from USA; based on paper presented in a symposium on triangulation and mixed methods research, International Congress of Qualitative Inquiry, University of Illinois, 2010.

Title: Disrupting ‘anorexia nervosa’: an ethnography of the Deleuzian event
AdditionalInformation: Chapter in a leading international series on the work of Deleuze – the first such book in the UK. Primarily methodological, but draws on the author's empirical research on intervention programmes in schools, the chapter provides an innovative perspective on young people and anorexia.

Title: Utilising a blended ethnographic approach to explore the online and offline lives of pro-ana community members
AdditionalInformation: Published in the leading journal on ethnography and education, in a special issue dealing with research in online contexts. The article offers a critique of the separation of online and offline research.  Based on Dyke’s doctoral research, the material has been presented at the International Congress of Qualitative Inquiry, Illinois 2012 and the British Educational Research Association Annual Conference 2011.

Title: The wonder of method
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Research & Method in Education
AdditionalInformation: Published in special edition: ‘European Philosophy and Theory: New Bearings in Educational Research Methodology’;  theoretical critique of the limits of humanism in educational philosophy and research, arguing the case for theories of difference.

Title: The Politics of Becoming: . . . Making Time . . .
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading international journal edited from USA; provocative argument in favour of inter-subjective relations for inquiry and pedagogy while remaining skeptical of being able to ‘know the other’.

Title: The Life of Suggestions
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading international journal edited from USA; develops the use of Deleuzian theory in educational research. Based on a presentation to the prestigious and influential First International Deleuze Studies Conference, Cardiff 2008.

Title: Who’s Afraid of Research?
AdditionalInformation: Published in special edition of international journal edited from the USA; draws on involvement in several empirical projects to develop an innovative critique of conventional ethics principles and procedures, focusing on the social and political conditions of research practice.

Title:
Writing Research Critically
Developing the power to make a difference
AdditionalInformation: Draws on original research including a Barclays Bank funded evaluation of ‘Spaces for Sport’. Develops a novel theoretical and analytic approach to ‘writing’ as a radical research methodology,

Title: Researching and Representing Wrongs, Injuries and Disagreements: exploring strategies for radical research
AdditionalInformation: Substantial review of key issues for launch of new journal - journal of the international Discourse Power Resistance (DPR) conference. Paper first presented to research seminar, University of Sussex

Title: Cinemaethnographic Specta(c)torship: Discursive Readings of What We Choose to (Dis)possess
AdditionalInformation: Significant methodological paper based on an ESRC-funded ethnographic study (RES–062-23-0105) and Follow-on project (RES-189-25-01220). Originally presented to the American Education Research Association Annual Meeting 2009.

Title: Theatre of the self: autobiography as performance
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Qualitative Studies in Education
AdditionalInformation: Interrogates the shifting landscape of HE under pressure from discourses of economic rationality and the widening participation’ agenda. Originally presented at the International Conference in Critical Psychology, Cultural Studies and Social Theory, Cardiff University 2008. The article was selected for inclusion in the Handbook of Qualitative Research in Education (S. Delamont ed, Edward Elgar, 2012) and Social Theory and Education Research (M. Murphy ed, Sage 2012).

Title: Risky Pleasures: Using the Work of Graffiti Writers to Theorise the Act of Ethnography
AdditionalInformation: Draws on ESRC projects (RES–062-23-0105; RES-189-25-01220) and informed a successful ESRC Seminar Series bid, Generating Alternative Discourses of Childhood as a Resource for Educational Policy Making (RES-451-26-0948). Mobilises the notion of graffiti to challenge traditional views of classrooms and reinvigorate ethnographic inquiry.

Title: The offence of theory
AdditionalInformation: Major theoretical contribution to the research/policy/practice debate, drawing on empirical material from ESRC project (RES–062-23-0105); originally presented to BERA Conference  symposium on the Role of Theory in Educational Research (2009).

Title: Qualitative Inquiry: Where Are the Ruins?
AdditionalInformation: Published in leading journal edited from USA; based on keynote presentation to the New Zealand Association for Research in Education (NZARE) 2010. Significant contribution to methodology in educational and social research addressing the epistemological claims and practical implications of the postmodern ‘turn’ in theory.

Title: Storytelling as Methodology: Colombia’s Social Studies Textbooks after La Constitución de 1991
AdditionalInformation: QRE is edited from Spain, published in Spanish and English, with an international editorial board. As an on-line-open access journal it has the potential to reach a wider audience than English-only publications. The bilingual and online format is especially important for this article, written in both Spanish and English.

Title: Complicity as Infiltration: The (Im)possibilities of Research With/in NSF Engineering Grants in the Age of Neoliberal Scientism

Creativity and Education Futures: Learning in a Digital Age
DoubleWeightingStatement: This is a sole-authored academic monograph of 173 pages offering extended analysis of children’s childhoods in a digital age and implications for creative educational provision.  The book includes empirical research data from USA and UK and explores a number of theoretical positions and perspectives drawing on an extensive international literature.  Offering a unique account of childhoods with reference to creativity and digital technologies the implications for schools and school systems prompted two EU-funded studies:  C2Learn (OU, 2012-15) and CREATIT (Exeter, 2013-15).  This text involved ‘exceptional research effort’ (Main Panel C criterion) synthesizing a wide literature and generating original perspectives.
