This paper resulted in an invitation from the editor of the International Journal of Science Education to present the findings at the European Science Education Research Association conference as an example of a significant paper published in the journal in 2012.

Title: Using the Internet in science teaching? Issues and challenges for initial teacher education
AdditionalInformation: This paper report on part of a five-year longitudinal research project by the universities of  Oxford, Nottingham and Loughborough. The research has been presented at conferences of the European Science Education Research Association and the American Educational Research Association.

Title: Teacher Education in 21st Century England. A Case Study in Neoliberal Public Policy
VolumeTitle: The Spanish Journal of Comparative Education (Revista Espanola de Educacion Comparada)
AdditionalInformation: We were invited by The Spanish journal of Comparative Education (Revista Espanola de Educacion Comparada) contribute to a monograph on "Teacher education in the XXI century" about the case of England. The paper prompted an invitation to give a keynote presentation at a conference organised by Kings College and Goldsmith's College to contribute to national and international debate about the policy trajectory of teacher education in England.

Title: School subject departments as sites for science teachers learning pedagogical content knowledge
AdditionalInformation: Research on science teacher learning has focused principally on learning pedagogical content knowledge (PCK) in Initial Teacher Education or Continuing Professional Development programmes. This study opens up the 'black box' of the school subject department and, for the first time in the literature, examines the school context as a potential site  learning PCK. It is a key paper in our ongoing programme of research in this area.

Title: Vygotsky and Research
AdditionalInformation: This is the third volume in a much cited series by the author.  It has led to a keynote invitation at the 2014 ISCAR conference in Sydney and has been translated into Portuguese in Brazil.

Title: Exclusion from school: short-term setback or a long term of difficulties?
VolumeTitle: European Journal of Special Needs Education
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a 2 year follow up of 200 pupils who were excluded from school and did not return to the mainstream. It formed the basis for the development of the central arguments in: Cole, T., Daniels, H.. and Visser, J (2012) The Routledge International Companion to  Emotional and Behavioural Difficulties. London: Routledge Visser, J Daniels, H.. and Cole, T. (Eds) (2012 ) Transforming Troubled Lives: Strategies and Interventions for Children with Social, Emotional and Behavioural Difficulties London: Sage

Title: The mutual shaping of human action and institutional settings:  a study of the transformation of childrens services and professional work
VolumeTitle: The British Journal of Sociology of Education
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the ESRC (final report graded outstanding). It has led to more than 10 invitations to speak at conferences and seminars

Title: Changing Situations and Motives
VolumeTitle: Motives in Children's Development: Cultural-Historical Approaches

Title: Teenagers and Technology
Digitally strategic: how young people respond to parental views about the use of technology for learning in the home
VolumeTitle: Journal of Computer and Assisted Learning
AdditionalInformation: This paper was included in a special issue for JCAL on parental engagement in children?s uses of technologies for learning, July 2011, for which I was joint editor (with Prof Carey Jewitt). JCAL has an impact factor of 2.095, and is ranked 20 in list of educational research journals.

Title: Young People, New Technologies and Learning at Home: Taking context seriously
AdditionalInformation: This article was included in a special issue of the Oxford Review of Education on digital technologies in the lives of young people, in February 2012, for which I was joint guest editor with Prof Sonia Livingstone and Dr John Coleman. The article was the third most downloaded article via Taylor & Francis online between January-August 2013, at 1,591 downloads. The special issue has subsequently been selected for publication as a book by Routledges special books as issues programme.

Title: Assessing the accuracy and quality of Wikipedia entries compared to popular online encyclopaedias: A preliminary comparative study across disciplines in English, Spanish and Arabic
The Role of Common Knowledge in Achieving Collaboration across Practices
AdditionalInformation: Based on the  keynote given when awarded an honorary doctorate at the University of Oslo for my work on relational expertise and relational agency. The article explains  the additional concept of common knowledge and its role in mediating the exercise of relational expertise. It was placed after refereeing in the founding issue of a new journal as an exemplar of the kinds of papers welcomed by the journal.

Title: Improving inter-professional collaborations: multi-agency working for children?s wellbeing
AdditionalInformation: Based on an ESRC-TLRP study rated outstanding. Short-listed for the NASEN academic book prize 2011. Has led to invited national and international research keynotes and workshops (Denmark, Finland, Italy, Norway, Spain)and an invited research review on inter-professional work  for the European Commission.

Title: Inter-professional Work and Expertise: new roles at the boundaries of schools
AdditionalInformation: Based on ESRC study rated outstanding. Used a key reading on a number of masters courses in the UK and a research review for the Children?s Workforce Development Council.

Title: Being an expert professional practitioner: the relational turn in expertise
AdditionalInformation: Brings together work from three ESRC studies all rated outstanding and studies funded by DfES and DCSF. The key ideas in this book ? relational expertise, relational agency and resourceful practice-  have led to two honorary doctorates (Helsinki and Oslo) and are informing research studies in Australia and Finland and  New Zealand  as well as the UK

Title: German Higher Education and the State: A critical appraisal in the light of post-Bologna reforms?
VolumeTitle: Higher Education and the State: changing relationships in Europe and East Asia

Title: Employing an 'employer-led' design? An evaluation of the development of Diplomas
AdditionalInformation: This paper is the outcome of a number of evaluation projects funded by DCSF and QCA in the context of the development of Diplomas.

Title: The Transition from Vocational Education and Training to Higher Education: A successful pathway?
AdditionalInformation: This paper is based on research conducted for a TLRP project on transitions from vocational to higher education. The work was part of a HEFCE-funded series of TLRP projects on widening participation in higher education and also forms a substantial part of Improving Learning on Diversity of Access to and Participation in Higher Education, published in the Routledge Gateway Improving Learning series.

Title: Das Publikationsaufkommen der Zeitschrift fur Padagogik im deutsch-englischen Vergleich
EnglishAbstract: This article presents selected results of an analysis of papers published in six leading journals of education in Germany and England. All articles published in these journals between 2001 and 2009 (around 2000 in total) were analysed according to thematic foci, methodological approaches and characteristics of authors. The findings demonstrate that there are clear differences and similarities in publication patterns between different journals and countries and that some of these patterns have changed substantially over time. The comparative perspective used for the analysis results in conclusions regarding nation-specific trajectories of the discourse and research in the area of education.
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents the results of work undertaken in the context of two competitive grants awarded by the German Research Association (Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft - DFG), won in collaboration with colleagues from the Universities of Munich and Oldenburg. According to SSCI the publishing journal Zeitschrift fur Padagogik was most highly cited German journal in education over the last decade. The paper led to an invitation to present the research findings in the context of a 'DFG Colloquium' event in Munich in October 2013.

Title: Enhancing parents' ways of supporting their children's early learning through participation in an early-intervention project in the UK: The Early Learning Partnership Project
AdditionalInformation: This article was an invited paper for the German Journal of Family Research.  The article was based on a DCSF-funded project that evaluated an ambitious government intervention with Hard to Reach families.

Title: From hard to reach to how to reach: A systematic review of the literature on hard-to-reach families
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a systematic review of the literature, awarded funding from the Brian Simon Educational Research Fellowship, BERA (2006/7) for the project: A systematic review on ?hard-to-reach? families.  A summary of the article first appeared in Research Intelligence.

Title: Early years learning and development: literature review
AdditionalInformation: This report was commissioned by the DfE. It had a direct impact on the review of the Early Years Foundation Stage Curriculum and Framework in England. It has been referenced numerous times in the reviewed EYFS document and has been discussed widely by academics and researchers working in the early years field.

Title: What Makes a Successful Transition from Primary to Secondary School?
AdditionalInformation: This is a report commissioned by the DCSF. It is part of a series of reports from the Effective Provision of Pre-School, Primary and Secondary Education Project (EPPSE).  It is one of very few studies exploring children's experience during their transition between primary and secondary school, that is based upon a representative sample in England and has therefore attracted interest from academics and researchers working in the early years field.

Title: Understanding the online information-seeking behaviours of young people: the role of networks of support
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a large scale research project funded by BECTA. The findings were first presented at EARLI in 2011 and published in JCAL in 2012. JCAL is ranked 20th of all Education and Educational Research journals in ISI, with a 5 year impact factor of 2.095.

Title: Adults Learning Online: Digital Choice and/or Digital Exclusion?
AdditionalInformation: The findings from this article were first presented as a keynote address for the NIACE Digital Inclusion Conference in 2008 and then published in 2011 in New Media and Society. NMS has a five year impact factor of 2.298.

Title: A typology of young peoples Internet use: implications for education
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a large scale research project funded by BECTA. The results were first presented at BERA in 2009 and then published in 2011 in Computers and Education. CaE has a five year impact factor of 3.305 and is ranked 7th of all Education and Educational Research journals in ISI.

Title: Digital natives: where is the evidence?
Religious education across Europe: contexts in policy scholarship
VolumeTitle: Exploring context in religious education research: empirical, methodological and theoretical perspectives

Title: Education: an anatomy of the discipline. Rescuing the university project?
DoubleWeightingStatement: This book is equivalent to three or more journal articles. It focuses on the development of education as a discipline, how it is currently understood and practised and threats to its future. The culmination of four years of work, it draws on wide range of different forms of scholarship (historical analysis, policy sociology, philosophical analysis and case studies of education departments in 10 UK universities) providing a comprehensive overview of the field. Topics include the historical development of the discipline; the current shape of educational teaching and research; the changing nature of universities; challenges for the future of the discipline.
AdditionalInformation: Based on four years work, the book brings together historical, sociological, philosophical and empirical analysis to review the 'discipline' of education in the UK today and the future.  Invited Key Note addresses on the book include:  2012 : BERA, Manchester; The BERA Symposium at AARE, Sydney; 2013: Higher Education Academy Teaching and Learning symposium; Institute for Research in the Social Sciences Annual Lecture, University of Ulster; BESA, Swansea. A full length feature article appeared in the THES http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/features/educationalists-must-do-better/2003518.fullarticle. A follow-up British Academy project (The Discipline of Education in Different Jurisdictions)  will examine the discipline in a range of different countries.

Title: Making Teaching a 21st Century Profession: Tony Blairs big prize
AdditionalInformation: This paper was part of a special edition of the Oxford Review of Education reviewing 10 years of education under New Labour

Title: The Disciplines of Education in the UK: between the ghost and the shadow
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the opening paper of a special edition of the Oxford Review of Education. With the addition of further chapters (including Furlong, J and Lawn, M (2010) ?Disciplines of education and their role in the future of educational research ? concluding reflections? ) it was republished as a book: Furlong, J and Lawn M.  (2010) (eds)  The Disciplines of Education: their role in the future of education research. London: Routledge.  A Key Note Symposium based on book was given at BERA 2009; the symposium was also selected as the  BERA Symposium at AERA 2010, New Orleans, USA.

Title: Partnership, policy and politics: initial teacher education in England under New Labour
VolumeTitle: Teachers and Teaching: Theory and Practice
AdditionalInformation: This paper draws on a TDA funded research project examining the development of ?partnership? in initial teacher education in England. The paper formed part of special edition of Teachers and Teaching :Furlong, J, Cochran Smith, M and Brennan, M (Eds) Teachers and Teaching: Politics and Policy in Teacher Education: international perspectives  Volume 14 (4) 307-318. With the addition of further papers, the special edition was also republished as a book Furlong, J, Cochran Smith, M and Brennan, M (2008)  (eds), Politics and Policy in Teacher Education: international perspectives London: Routledge.

Title: On Holy Ground: The Theory and Practice of Religious Education
DoubleWeightingStatement: What are the epistemological grounds of modern religious education? Through a systematic cross-disciplinary analysis, in historical and contemporary perspective, answering this question was the ambitious task of On Holy Ground. The product of three years’ systematic theoretical research, the 100,000 word monograph provides a comprehensive investigation into the influences on religious education from philosophy and theology, the natural sciences, the social sciences, psychology, phenomenology, politics and the arts. A synthesis of an unusually broad range of literature, On Holy Ground presents a highly original thesis necessitating book-length (rather than separate article) treatment to produce a landmark work in the field.
AdditionalInformation: Through a systematic cross-disciplinary analysis, in historical and contemporary perspective, the monograph analyses the epistemological grounds of modern religious education. The product of three years systematic theoretical research, the book is receiving very warm reviews.

Title: Politics, literature and education: the literary archive in citizenship ? the case of Poets, Essayists, Novelists (PEN)
AdditionalInformation: Based on Leverhulme Trust funded research: Writers and their Dictators: Authors, Citizens, Educators. This work was pivotal in Gearon?s appointment as Conjoint Professor at the Humanities Research Institute, Newcastle University, Australia.

Title: The counter terrorist classroom: religion, education, and security
AdditionalInformation: Published in America?s leading journal of Religious Education.

Title: MasterClass in Religious Education : Transforming Teaching and Learning
AdditionalInformation: Commissioned as part of a series of critical studies interrogating contemporary curriculum theory and receiving extremely favorable reviews.

Title: Gender distinctive impacts of prematurity and small for gestational age (SGA) on age-6 attention problems
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by grants PKE24, JUG14, 01EP9504, and 01ER0801 from the German Federal Ministry of Education and Science (BMBF).

Title: Measuring the combined risk to young childrens cognitive development: An alternative to cumulative indices
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research that was supported by grants from the (then) UK Department for Education and Skills (DfES) and the UK Economic and Social Research Council.

Title: The role of pre-school quality in promoting resilience in the cognitive development of young children
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research that was supported by grants from the (then) UK Department for Education and Skills (DfES) and the UK Economic and Social Research Council.

Title: Effects of sensitive parenting on the academic resilience of very pre-term and v low birth weight adolescents
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by grants PKE24, JUG14, 01EP9504, and 01ER0801 from the German Federal Ministry of Education and Science (BMBF)

Title: Examining Evidence for the Validity of PISA Learning Strategy Scales Based on Student Response Processes
AdditionalInformation: The article is based on research funded by the Norwegian Directorate for Education and Training. It has been on the most read list the past two years for this journal: International Journal of Testing according to their records.

Title: Assessment with distinctly defined criteria: A research study of a National project
AdditionalInformation: This article is based upon research funded by the Norwegian Directorate for Education and Training.

Title: A Bermuda triangle of Policy? Bad jobs, skills policy and incentives to learn at the bottom end of the labour market
AdditionalInformation: The study was funded through ESRC centre?s funding

Title: Delivering flexibility: Contrasting patterns in the French and the UK food processing industry
AdditionalInformation: The study was funded through ESRC centre?s funding

Title: Developing Vocational Excellence: Learning Environments within Work Environments
Publisher: ESRC Centre on Skills Knowledge and Organisational Performance
AdditionalInformation: This paper builds upon a report submitted to the funders, which resulted in further funding being awarded for a series of projects. This funding was £649,093.20

Title: Tough Meat, Hard Candy: implications for low wage work in the food processing industry
VolumeTitle: Low Wage Work in the Wealthy World
AdditionalInformation: This article is based upon research funded by the Norwegian Directorate for Education and Training.

Title: Education and industry: taking two steps back and reflecting
Internal and external incentives to engage in education and training: a framework for analysing the forces acting on individuals?
Publisher: ESRC Centre on Skills Knowledge and Organisational Performance

Title: Moving beyond skills as a social and economic panacea
The English skills policy narrative
VolumeTitle: Post-Compulsory Education and Lifelong Learning across the United Kingdom: Policy, Organisation and Governance

Title: Differentiated associations between childhood maltreatment experiences and social understanding: a meta-analysis and systematic review
AdditionalInformation: In 2012 I was awarded a conference bursary from the British Psychological Society?s Developmental Section Committee, to present the results of this paper at their annual conference in Strathclyde

Title: Strategy instruction in listening for lower-intermediate learners of French
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the ESRC (final report graded outstanding) and for which Macaro was principal investigator. It has been described in a review of strategy research as being an excellent example of how research of this kind should be conducted. It is published in a very high ranking language acquisition journal (Impact Factor: 1.318)

Title: Decoding Ability in French as a Foreign Language and Language Learning Motivation
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the ESRC (final report graded outstanding) It is the only (according to searches) piece of published research to have linked decoding ability with motivation to study a second language. It is published in a very high ranking language acquisition journal (Impact Factor: 1.114)

Title: The medium of instruction and classroom interaction: evidence from Hong Kong secondary schools
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Bilingual Education and Bilingualism
AdditionalInformation: This article used, in part, a classroom interaction analysis technique developed by Macaro in previous research and publications to identify the classroom interaction in a context (academic subjects taught through the medium of English). Macaro has received university pump-priming funding for a research centre on this topic.

Title: Comparing the effect of teacher codeswitching with English-only explanations on the vocabulary acquisition of Chinese university students: a lexical focus-on-form study
AdditionalInformation: This is the only (according to searches) published research which uses an experimental design to establish whether teacher codeswitching has a positive or negative effect on students? vocabulary acquisition.

Title: Changes in student teachers agency beliefs during a teacher education year, and relationships with observed classroom quality, and day-to-day experiences
AdditionalInformation: The paper applied state-of-the-art statistical modelling for answering substantive research questions in education, during the prestigious Research Councils UK (RCUK) Academic Fellowship 2007-12. This article is based on research funded by the ESRC. It was presented as an invited paper in the SIG Keynote Symposium (Emotion and Motivation) at the European Association for Research on Learning and Instruction (EARLI) Biennial Conference, Amsterdam, The Netherlands, 22-25/08/2009.

Title: Effects of a pre-school intervention on cognitive development among East-African pre-school children: A flexibly time-coded growth model
AdditionalInformation: Educational intervention studies in sub-Saharan countries are scarce. The paper applied state-of-the-art statistical modelling for answering substantive research questions in education, during the prestigious Research Councils UK (RCUK) Academic Fellowship 2007-12.

Title: Age and school-type differences in childrens beliefs about school performance
AdditionalInformation: The paper applied state-of-the-art statistical modelling for answering substantive research questions in education, during the prestigious Research Councils UK (RCUK) Academic Fellowship 2007-12.

Title: Primary school students learning experiences of, and self-beliefs about competence, effort, and difficulty: Random effects models
AdditionalInformation: The paper applied state-of-the-art statistical modelling for answering substantive research questions in education, during the prestigious Research Councils UK (RCUK) Academic Fellowship 2007-12.

Title: Doubly-latent models of school contextual effects: Integrating multilevel and structural equation approaches to control measurement and sampling error
AdditionalInformation: Definitive ?state of the art? multilevel latent-variable approach to evaluating contextual effects and contextual value-added (CVA) models with broad applicability across the social sciences. Integrates structural equation and multilevel models of contextual/climate effects to evaluate school effectiveness, and school-to-school variation in effectiveness used to construct league tables. This is the primary paper from my ESRC Professorial Fellowship to develop better CVA models of school effectiveness; basis of invited keynote addresses to 2009 International Meeting of the Psychometric Society on its statistical basis and to 2010 Research Methodology Festival symposium on League Tables

Title: The Big-Fish-Little-Pond-Effect Stands Up to Critical Scrutiny: Implications for Theory, Methodology, and Future Research
AdditionalInformation: Definitive substantive and methodological review substantiating my highly controversial big-fish-little-pond effect (BFLPE; negative effects of school-average achievement associated with attending academically selective schools), one of psychology?s most cross-culturally universal phenomena based on PISA data with important policy-practice implications. Basis of invited keynote addresses to 2010 International Congress of Psychology, 2009 World Congress of Positive Psychology, 2010 Biennial SELF Research Conference.

Title: Improving the peer-review process for grant applications: Reliability, validity, bias and generalization
AdditionalInformation: Peer review is widely used to evaluate most academic outcomes. This summarises my research on psychology?s most widely read journal; my multilevel statistical approach that is becoming the standard in this area; substantive demonstration of serious problems but also reforms that improved peer review. Shortlisted for APA George A. Miller Award for best contribution to general Psychology. Basis of: commentary in Nature (2009); invited keynotes: International Meeting of the Science and Technology (2010), international conference ?Evolutions in peer review? (2013); Master Class, Dutch National Research Council (2009)

Title: Construct validity of the multidimensional structure of bullying and victimization: An application of exploratory structural equation modeling
AdditionalInformation: The article presents our Beyond Bullying Intervention; psychometrically strong, multidimensional battery of bullying/victimization measures (likely to be widely used due to dearth of existing measures), 2011 endorsement by USA Centre of Disease Control. Methodologically, introduces ESEM, a revolutionary new psychometric/statistical tool integrating confirmatory and exploratory factor analyses that is critical for applied psychological measurement; basis of the invited methodological chapter for Annual Review of Clinical Psychology; keynote International Congress of Psychology.

Title: Quality in Early Childhood Education
VolumeTitle: Contemporary Issues in the Early Years

Title: Improving Quality in the Early Years: a comparison of perspectives and measures
Evaluation of the Graduate Leader Fund: Impact Study Final Report
Childcare in the Pre-School Years
VolumeTitle: Children of the 21st Century: The First Five years

Title: Low pay, labour market institutions and job quality in the UK
VolumeTitle: Low Wage Work in the UK

Title: Industrial relations, legal regulations and wage setting
VolumeTitle: Low Wage Work in the Wealthy World
AdditionalInformation: The Russell Sage Foundation funded this work as a ?follow-on? to the project mentioned in the information on Skill; the solution to low wage work.  The Foundation retained a proportion of the European researchers who had been engaged on this project and asked them to collaborate with a group of American academics.  The aim was to compare the European findings with the position of the low paid in the US.

Title: The economic record of the 1997?2010 Labour government: an assessment
AdditionalInformation: Much of the material in this article was also derived from SKOPE research.

Title: Skill: the solution to low wage work?
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the New York based Russell Sage Foundation.  It was part of a project which funded five European teams to work to a common research design to produce an analysis of the future of low end work.  The teams came from the UK, France, Germany, Denmark and the Netherlands.  Mayhew was joint-leader of the UK team.  The article was shortlisted for the annual Sage Prize for Innovation and/or Excellence awarded by the British Sociological Association.

Title: Effects of the Home Learning Environment and preschool center experience upon literacy and numeracy development in early primary school
AdditionalInformation: This article draws on a longitudinal DCSF-funded study.  It provides the evidence underpinning the Home Learning Environment (HLE) measure.  It demonstrates the contribution of the HLE to the later independent development of demographic and other factors.  This evidence has stimulated government-led initiatives to improve the HLE for young children as in the DfE document  ?Supporting Families in the Foundation Years? . Data from the article are used in the Field Review, on child poverty (2010) and The Allen Review  Early Intervention (2011). It has also  inspired Scottish government to fund similar research.

Title: Preschool influences on mathematics achievement
AdditionalInformation: This article is based upon the EPPE longitudinal research funded by DCSF.  This article provides evidence demonstrating the longer-term impact of preschool experience upon mathematics attainment of sufficient sophistication that a journal as prestigious as Science (impact factor 30+) published it.  Thus an example of educational evidence was taken to scientific audiences far beyond those normally open to educational research, with consequences for the prestige of the discipline.  It has featured on numerous websites, e.g. the National Institute for Early Education Research.

Title: Effects of fully-established Sure Start Local Programmes on 3-year-old children and their families living in England: a quasi-experimental observational study
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research by the National Evaluation of Sure Start funded by the DfE.  It was judged of sufficient research quality to be published by Lancet (impact factor 28).

Title: Preschool affects longer term literacy and numeracy: results from a general population longitudinal study in Northern Ireland
VolumeTitle: School Effectiveness and School Improvement: An International Journal of Research, Policy and Practice
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a longitudinal study funded by the government in Northern Ireland. It demonstrates the longer-term impact of preschool education on literacy and numeracy, independently of demographic and other factors in Northern Ireland, confirming the findings in the parallel EPPE study in England.

Title: Tradition, culture and identity in the reform of teachers work in Scotland and England: some methodological considerations
AdditionalInformation: This article draws in part on ten projects carried out in England and Scotland for, among others, the ESRC, NCSL, TTA and the Scottish Government.

Title: Four 'academic sub-tribes', but one territory? Teacher educators and teacher education in Scotland
AdditionalInformation: Commissioned for a special issue of Journal of Education for Teaching on the topic of teacher educators identities.

Title: Teacher education research in the UK: the state of the art
VolumeTitle: Revue suisse des sciences de l'education
AdditionalInformation: Menter was  first author - with a large team. The Teacher Education Group, a UK wide research group, was established with support from TLRP, ESCalate, UCET and BERA to generate a digital annotated bibliographic resource on teacher education research in the UK.  This paper was commissioned by a Swiss journal as part of a special issue on teacher education research in Europe.

Title: Literature review on teacher education in the 21st century
AdditionalInformation: Menter led a large team at the University of Glasgow to carry out this major literature review commissioned by the Scottish Government to support the Donaldson Review of teacher education in Scotland.  Donaldson has acknowledged the use he made of the review in writing his report and it has been widely used by teacher education scholars in the UK and elsewhere.

Title: Difficult Folk? A political history of social anthropology
AdditionalInformation: The research leading to this publication was carried out whilst holding a Leverhulme Special Research Fellowship, and with a British Academy Small Grant Award. In March 2013, the book was described by the President of the Association of Social Anthropologists, Professor James Fairhead, as a fascinating book on the history of the profession in an email sent to all members.

Title: Lively bureaucracy? The ESRC's Doctoral Training Centres and UK universities
After method? Ethnography in the knowledge economy
AdditionalInformation: The research in this article was also funded by the ESRC grant mentioned above. It led to a request to write a textbook on using ethnographic research methods in educational settings, published as Ethnography and Education (Mills and Morton 2013).

Title: Gender, Disembodiment and Vocation: Exploring the Unmentionables of British Academic Life
AdditionalInformation: This article draws partly on research funded by an ESRC large grant (RES-000-23-0220). It was republished in the SAGE Benchmarks in Social Research Methods volume entitled Qualitative Research Methods (2010) and edited by Paul Atkinson and Sara Delamont.

Title: Effect of frequency and idiomaticity on second language reading comprehension
AdditionalInformation: This project was the first study that empirically demonstrated that adult second language learners have difficulty with texts that include multiword phrases.  Furthermore, L2 learners under-estimate the difficulty they face, suggesting they fail to even recognise a multiword phrase when it appears in text.  It highlights the need to investigate phraseological vocabulary knowledge in greater detail from a range of perspectives.  This study has led to the development of cross-disciplinary funded research projects (e.g., Nation, Murphy & Pullman, FELL (University)fund award 2013/14) examining the nature of collocational knowledge in children.

Title: Processing English compounds in the first and second language:  the influence of the middle morpheme
AdditionalInformation: This paper was part of a special issue of the prestigious journal Language Learning which focussed on L2 learners? knowledge of inflectional morphology across a range of languages.  This paper was the only investigation these issues within the context of lexical phonology and derivational processes.  It is also the only paper which shows a direct relationship between the input and the nature of L2 learner?s knowledge of grammatical morphological processes.

Title: Morphosyntax in children with word finding difficulties
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the ESRC.  It was the first study to empirically investigate predictions of the influential dual-mechanism model within the context of lexical retrieval difficulties within primary school-aged children.  This work has helped to more closely identify the parameters of difficulty experienced by children with these lexical impairments and has helped contribute to theoretical understandings of how languages are learned and represented.

Title: A comparative study of listening comprehension measures in English as an additional language and native English-speaking primary school children
AdditionalInformation: This paper presents work that was funded by the ESRC through a doctoral fellowship awarded to the first author (supervised by the second author).  It is the first paper to illustrate the differential outcomes of listening comprehension measures in children with English as an Additional Language (EAL).  This empirical demonstration is important because researchers have been concerned about problems associated with measuring listening comprehension skills in young children.  This study demonstrates the impact of different listening comprehension measures which can help researchers make more informed choices about their dependent measures.

Title: Surprising but not shocking: the reality of the first year of teaching
Making sense of learning to teach: learners in context
AdditionalInformation: The article was one of the top cited articles in Research Papers in Education

Title: "We will take them from anywhere? ? schools working within multiple initial teacher training partnerships
VolumeTitle: Journal of Education for Teaching: International research and pedagogy

Title: Observed Classroom Quality During Teacher Education and Two Years of Professional Practice
The Relative Importance of Two Different Mathematical Abilities to Mathematical Achievement
AdditionalInformation: This article was based on a DCSF grant. After its publication, we were invited to give a paper in an invited symposium at EARLI 2013 entitled "Numeracy and arithmetic competence".

Title: Teaching children how to include the inversion principle in their reasoning about quantitative relations
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a TLRP-ESRC project. Following its publication, we were invited to present it at the 2013 EARLI Conference in the Invited Symposium organised by the SIG on conceptual change entitled "Continuity and change in the growth of children?s mathematical understanding".

Title: The scheme of correspondence and its role in children's mathematics
AdditionalInformation: This paper reports data from a hearing sample in a project supported by the RNID, which compared hearing and deaf. It provides evidence for the hypothesis that the scheme of correspondence, rather than repeated addition, forms the basis for multiplicative reasoning. The publication led to an invitation to give a key note address at the conference "Intersection of Language, Learning and Culture in Early Childhood: Home, school and community contexts" in the University of British Columbia, Canada.

Title: The development of word recognition and its significance for comprehension and fluency
AdditionalInformation: This article was based on a British Academy grant. The publication of this paper was followed by an invitation to contribute a chapter about this topic to the The Routledge Handbook of the English Writing System (Ed: Vivian Cook & Des Ryan). The volume is intended both as a state-of-the-art review of the main lines of development and an exploration of their implications for future research and thinking about written language.

Title: Philosophy of education in the UK: The historical and contemporary tradition
AdditionalInformation: This article led to an invited plenary presentation to the 2009 BERA conference, on ?The voices/s of philosophy in the conversation of educational research?. The article was re-printed by Routledge in ?Disciplines of Education?, a volume that formed the basis of a BERA symposium at AERA 2010.

Title: The importance of being thorough: On systematic accumulations of ?what works? in education research
AdditionalInformation: This article arose from an ESRC/TLRP-funded project (led by David Bridges) bringing together a group of philosophers of education to explore the epistemological basis of educational research. It was originally published in the peer-reviewed Journal of Philosophy of Education, and subsequently re-published in book format.

Title: Education for All: The future of education and training for 14-19 year olds
AdditionalInformation: This book is based on the 6-year review of all aspects of secondary education and training in England and Wales, supported by nearly ?1 million funding from the Nuffield Foundation. In 2010 the book won the second prize of the Society for Educational Studies Awards. The publication of the book was covered extensively in national media, which described it as the outcome of the ?biggest review in 14-19 education in 50 years? and informed a subsequent TLRP report.

Title: The future of teacher education
Governing by inspection? European inspectorates and the creation of a European education policy space
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on current ESRC funded research [RES -062-23-2241 Governing By Inspection: School Inspection and Education Governance in Scotland, England and Sweden] and focuses on findings from the first stage of this project, that mapped and analysed the growth of inspectorates in Europe. It is a successor to and continues the argument made in an earlier paper in Comparative Education [National policy brokering and the construction of the European Education Space in England, Sweden, Finland and Scotland Grek et al 2009] that is listed in the Journals most cited category.

Title: Governing Education through Data in England: From Regulation to Self-Evaluation
AdditionalInformation: This article was part of an invited special issue of the Journal of Education Policy entitled Fabricating Quality: Data and the New Governance of Education that was entirely devoted to publications from the ESRC/ESF funded project Governing By Numbers: data and education governance in Denmark, England, Finland, Scotland and Sweden [RES-00-23-1385] co-ordinated by Jenny Ozga. The introductory essay in the special issue provides details of the project methodology, so these are not included in this paper. This article is included by Routledge in both its most read and most cited listings.

Title: Accountability as a Policy Technology: accounting for education performance in Europe
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on recent research projects funded by the ESRC and the EU, knowledge of which led to an invitation to contribute to an interdisciplinary and international seminar on Welfare States and Changing Accountabilities in Europe at the European Studies Centre, St Anthonys College, Oxford. This in turn led to the invitation to submit the article for inclusion, subject to the normal reviewing process, in a special issue of IRAS, based on the seminar proceedings.

Title: The politics of educational change: governance and school inspection in England and Scotland
AdditionalInformation: This paper in the Swiss Journal of Sociology  is an invited contribution to a special issue on Change and Reforms in Educational Systems and Organizations. Our submission was requested by the editors because of their view of the significance of our research in offering resources for understanding change in European education systems. The article was subject to the normal reviewing processes. It is based on current ESRC funded research [RES -062-23-2241 Governing By Inspection: School Inspection and Education Governance in Scotland, England and Sweden]

Title: Aspects of educational transfer
AdditionalInformation: This chapter synthesises a large body of work on educational transfer, developed by me and others in Oxford.  The so-called ?Oxford models? for investigating educational ?borrowing? are widely used in the work of academics around the world.

Title: The German example: English interest in educational provision in Germany since 1800
DoubleWeightingStatement: This book is the equivalent to at least three journal articles. It presents an analysis of how British policy-makers have used the example of education in Germany over the past 200 years to support or to argue against reform. The research and writing have taken four years with extensive surveys of UK archival material, together with detailed library research in Oxford, London and Berlin. The material drawn upon was vast, consisting of government reports, journal and newspaper accounts, and personal reminiscences and papers.  The findings are set within original theories of ‘educational policy transfer’, developed over the same period.
AdditionalInformation: This book is the result of several years of archival work and wide reading, covering sources in English and German.  It is the first study of its kind, and much of the research involved was funded by the German Academic Exchange Service (DAAD) which allowed me to spend time in research libraries in Berlin. It has been reviewed in the German weekly Die Zeit and in the leading German journal Bildung und Erziehing

Title: Aspects of education for democratic citizenship in post-war Germany
AdditionalInformation: This paper includes some original archival material on the post-war occupation of Germany, published here for the first time.  It builds on work on the British Zone of Germany with which I have been involved for 30+ years, originally funded by the Volkswagen-Stiftung and the DAAD.

Title: International comparisons of educational attainment: purposes, processes and problems
Exploring the impact of school leadership on pupil outcomes: Results from a study of academically improved and effective schools in England
AdditionalInformation: This paper draws on a major study of the role of school  leadership in shaping pupils educational outcomes in England  funded  by the DfE & National College.  It is the first study to identify effective and improving schools based on national  value added  data  across  three successive years and link survey results from head teachers and key staff  to provide measures of school processes. Results contributed to  a BERA Keynote  Symposium  in 2010.  It  received the  2012 Outstanding  Paper Award in  the Emerald Literati Network Awards for Excellence.

Title: Childrens cognitive attainment and progress in English primary schools during Key Stage 2: investigating the potential continuing influences of pre-school education
AdditionalInformation: This paper is based on research funded by the DfE using longitudinal data collected for a major study of childrens progress and development across different phases of education (Effective Provision of Pre-school, Primary and Secondary Education 3-16 project). It is the first study employing an educational effectiveness design to study the continuing effects of pre-school experiences  on childrens academic progress up to the end of primary schooling in England. Results informed the design of the major BIKS study of pre-school effects in Germany.

Title: The influence of child, family, home factors and pre-school education on the identification of special educational needs at age 10
AdditionalInformation: This paper is based on research funded by the DfE using longitudinal data on  childrens progress and development (Effective Provision of Pre-school, Primary and Secondary Education 3-16 project). The results  contribute to understanding of   how better  early years experiences can act as a protective influence in fostering better educational outcomes in primary school.

Title: Protecting the development of 5-11 year olds from the impacts of early disadvantage: the role of primary school academic effectiveness
VolumeTitle: School Effectiveness and School Improvement: An International Journal of Research, Policy and Practice
AdditionalInformation: This paper uses  longitudinal data on childrens progress and development across different phases of education (Effective Provision of Pre-school, Primary and Secondary Education 3-16 project funded by DfE). Findings were presented  at a BERA Keynote symposium in 2011  and the paper  published in a special issue of  School Effectiveness & School Improvement  focussing on  educational effectiveness approaches to   early childhood education research in Europe.

Title: Systematic review of research evidence of the impact on students in secondary schools of self and peer assessment
Publisher: Social Science Research Unit, Institute of Education
AdditionalInformation: This EPPI systematic review report was commissioned by DfES and looked specifically at peer and self-assessment as a key component of AFL which was being implemented through the national secondary strategy.

Title: Improving research through user engagement
AdditionalInformation: This book drew substantially on the ESRC-funded seminar series co-directed by Sebba and Edwards ? final report rated ?outstanding?. Sebba contributed chapters 4, 5 and 7 though the final text was a collaborative effort between the three authors. A paper was given on this research at BERA (2005), a symposium at AERA (2007) and keynotes in Ontario (Ministry of Education, 2009), Oslo (OECD, 2011), and LSE (ESRC Knowledge Transfer series, 2011). Work on research mediation developed from this.

Title: The teaching and learning of pupils in low-attainment sets
AdditionalInformation: Paper reporting on a mixed method DfES funded research project on ability-grouping and teaching.  The main significance of the findings was to demonstrate that pupils from lower socio-economic backgrounds had a higher probability of being placed in lower sets irrespective of prior attainment. Viewed 1061 times June 2011-July 2013, it is currently listed as the 11th most read article on the Journal?s website (July 2013)

Title: An exploratory review of the role of research mediators in social science knowledge transfer
AdditionalInformation: Building on the user engagement work, 3-months as visiting professor with the Research Supporting Practice in Education Team, OISE in Ontario was the basis for this review revised and updated in 2012. It was presented at a University of Birmingham invitation (VC, Prof David Eastwood) seminar and summarised in an LSE blog  which has been viewed 4592 times following the keynote at a conference on research impact at LSE, June 2011, from which this special issue of Evidence and Policy emanated. Another keynote was given to the Israeli Academy of Science/ Ministry of Education conference in Dec 2012.

Title: Take the Gift of My Child and Return Something to Me: On Children, Chagga Trust, and a New American Evangelical Orphanage on Mount Kilimanjaro.
Faith in schools: religion, education, and American evangelicals in East Africa
DoubleWeightingStatement: Data collection in Africa spanned 2000 – 2006 plus visits to US Christian Universities and the Billy Graham Archives in Illinois. The 272-page book was largely written during a 9-month sabbatical when a Visiting Scholar with the African Studies Program - University of Toronto. Chapters 4-6 are each equivalent to one journal article, as each deal with different countries (Tanzania, Kenya, and Uganda) therefore with three separate research trips and three substantially different literatures: Tanzania on national language policy; Kenya on the national system of HE; and Uganda on a geographically remote field site requiring review of an obscure literature.

Title: Education, religion, and anthropology in Africa
AdditionalInformation: This invited review essay appears in the Annual Review of Anthropology, a series that relies on experts in the field to provide authoritative synopses and analyses of key issues.

Title: Pedagogy and the paradox of American evangelical involvement in East African schools
VolumeTitle: Discourse: Studies in the Cultural Politics of Education

Title: The White British-Black Caribbean achievement gap: Tests, tiers and teacher expectations
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the England Department for Education. It was delivered as a keynote address to the Department for Children, Schools and Families (DCSF) / Department for Innovation, Universities and Skills (DIUS) Joint Annual Research Conference in 2008.  BERA has commissioned an INSIGHT article based on the research (Insights are accessible pamphlets designed to engage policy and practitioner communities with timely and excellent research on important educational issues).

Title: The limits of social class in explaining ethnic gaps in educational attainment
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the England Department for Education (EOR/SBU/2006/031).  It was delivered as a keynote address to the Department for Children, Schools and Families (DCSF) / Department for Innovation, Universities and Skills (DIUS) Joint Annual Research Conference in 2008.  BERA has commissioned an INSIGHT article based on the research (Insights are accessible pamphlets designed to engage policy and practitioner communities with timely and excellent research on important educational issues).

Title: Evidence of ethnic disproportionality in special education in an  English population
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on a research review specifically funded by the England Department of Education JSE is a highly cited journal, five year impact factor 2.20.

Title: Do some schools narrow the gap? Differential school effectiveness by ethnicity, gender, poverty and prior attainment
AdditionalInformation: SESI is the pre-eminent journal in the field, and this article is in the top dozen all time most read articles

Title: Facilitating the transition from empirical arguments to proof
VolumeTitle: Journal for Research in Mathematics Education
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the Spencer Foundation.

Title: Reasoning-and-proving in school mathematics textbooks
AdditionalInformation: This article received the 2011 American Educational Research Association SIG/RME Early Career Publication Award. The analytic framework discussed in the article has been adapted and used by other researchers in their analyses of textbooks at different levels of education, from the elementary to the university (for example, the five articles in a forthcoming International Journal of Education Research special issue have all used adapted versions of the framework). A U.S. National Science Foundation funded research project (PI: Margaret Smith, University of Pittsburgh) has used the framework as a guiding tool for the development of a teacher education curriculum on reasoning-and-proving.

Title: Cognitive anatomy of tutor learning: Lessons learned with SimStudent
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the U.S. National Science Foundation (Award No. DRL-0910176) and the U.S. Department of Education, Institute of Education Sciences (Grant R305A090519).

Title: A type of parental involvement with isomorphic effect on urban children?s mathematics, reading, science, and social studies achievement at Kindergarten entry
Pre-school quality and educational outcomes at age 11: Low quality has little benefit.
AdditionalInformation: This paper was the first to demonstrate that only academic quality, measured by the new ECERS-E ( Sylva et al. 2010)had benefits at age 11. More global quality  as measured on the well known ECERS-R rating scale did not lead to higher academic attainment at end of primary education. The findings from this study led to a successful bid to the EU for funding to study the nature and effects of pre-school quality across Europe (Project CARE 2014-2017)

Title: Effects of early child-care on cognition, language, and task-related behaviours at 18 months: An English study
AdditionalInformation: This is the largest prospective study of the effects of early childcare (0-3 years). The Sainsbury Trusts awarded it a further grant to make its datasets freely available to international researchers.

Title: The effects of early experiences at home and pre-school on gains in English and mathematics in primary school: a multilevel study in England
AdditionalInformation: This is the first study (in any country) to demonstrate that high quality education not only leads to a stronger academic profile at school entry but also leads to accelerated learning (compared to control children) throughout primary schooling. Too soon for reports of citation.

Title: Training parents to help their children read: A randomised control trial
VolumeTitle: The British Journal of Educational Psychology
AdditionalInformation: The successful small-scale efficacy trial of the SPOKES parent training programme led to a large-scale (N=700 children and families) effectiveness trial funded by the Education Endowment Foundation, 2012-2015.

Title: The Social Construction of Competition for Graduate Jobs; a Comparison between Great Britain and the Netherlands
A systematic review of CALL in English as a second language: Focus on primary and secondary education
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by Oxford University Press.  It was first presented at the British Association for Applied Linguistics conference in 2010.  In January-September 2013, it was viewed on academia.edu on average 14 times a month.

Title: Phonology in Second Language Reading: Not an Optional Extra
AdditionalInformation: The research presented in this article was first presented in a plenary lecture at the International Association of Teachers of English as a Foreign Language in 2009, and has since been presented in invited plenaries in four European countries .  In January-September 2013, it was viewed on academia.edu on average 39 times a month.

Title: Foreign language learning motivation in higher education: a longitudinal study of motivational changes and their causes
English and Malay Text Messages and What They Say about Texts and Cultures
Morphological Congruency and the Acquisition of L2 Morphemes
Direct evidence of the left caudates role in bilingual control: An intra-operative electrical stimulation study
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research supported by grants from National Basic Research Program of China (973 Program, No. 2011CB707804) awarded to Professor Tao Jiang and National MOE (Ministry of Education) Academic Research Fund Tier 1 of National University of Singapore (R-103-000-069-112) awarded to Dr Xin Wang.

Title: Language dominance in translation priming: Evidence from balanced and unbalanced Chinese?English bilinguals
VolumeTitle: The Quarterly Journal of Experimental Psychology 2012 - iFirst
AdditionalInformation: This article is based on research funded by the National MOE (Ministry of Education) Academic Research Fund Tier 1 of National University of Singapore (R-103-000-069-112) awarded to Dr. Xin Wang. It was also presented as an invited talk/paper at the Second Language Research Talk Series hosted by the National Research Center for Foreign Language Education, Beijing, China, in December 2010.

Title: Masked translation priming with semantic categorization: Testing the Sense Model
AdditionalInformation: This study was presented as an invited keynote at the International Conference on Language-Cognition Interface in December, 2009, organized by the Center for Behavioral and Cognitive Science, India.

Title: Learning coherent mathematics through sequences of microtasks: making a difference for secondary learners
VolumeTitle: International Journal of Science and Mathematics Education
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of a series arising from the funded project: Changes in Mathematics Teaching (CMTP) funded by Esmee Fairbairn Foundation. The paper is cited in the response of the Advisory Committee on Mathematics Education to ACME?s response to the National College for Teaching and Leadership?s consultation on pre-ITT subject knowledge enhancement.

Title: Shifts of mathematical thinking in adolescence
AdditionalInformation: This paper is in the top ten papers accessed in the journal Research in Mathematics Education. An early version of it was selected for the first annual volume: The Best Writing on Mathematics 2010 (M. Pitici ed.) Princeton University Press.

Title: Algebraic reasoning
AdditionalInformation: This synthesis was funded by the Nuffield Foundation and is freely available on their website. It synthesises findings from over 95 research papers selected on the basis of research quality, relevance and uniqueness from a much wider search. The algebra strand of the national curriculum is heavily dependent on this synthesis, as is a chapter in the book: Key Ideas in Teaching Mathematics 9-19, Watson, Jones and Pratt, Oxford University Press.

Title: Qualities of examples in learning and teaching
AdditionalInformation: This paper is one of a body of work on the use of examples in mathematics teaching and learning (see http://www.education.ox.ac.uk/about-us/directory/professor-anne-watson/ for a full list) which has been cited over 500 times.  This paper appeared in a special issue based on an invited workshop at the University of Siena on The Role of Mathematical Examples in Argumentation & Proof, and in Conceptualization & Definition. The workshop itself was in part informed by this body of work, as can be seen from the citations in the special issue.

Title: The Question of Morale: managing happiness and unhappiness in university life
AdditionalInformation: This single-authored book was the Times Higher Education book of the week in November 2009 and has been widely and generously reviewed and referenced.  It is credited with probing delicate and uncomfortable facets of contemporary university life, of drawing on a ?breath-taking range of sources? (THE) and offering a ? a role model for reflective practice? (Higher Education Review).  It has been widely used across and beyond higher education (including by the Bishops of the Church of England) as a stimulus to thinking and action in the leadership and management of complex, knowledge-based organisations.

Title: Learning Through Life: Inquiry into the Future for Lifelong Learning
AdditionalInformation: Watson was the Chair and Schuller the Director of the independent Commission on the Future of Lifelong Learning (supported by a ?1m grant from the National Institute of Adult and Continuing Education [NIACE] and working between 2007 and 2009).  Among the key contributions made by the volume are the first comprehensive account of spending from all sources on all types of post-compulsory education and training in the UK and a new four-stage model for understanding the educational life-course.

Title: The Engaged University: international perspectives on civic engagement
AdditionalInformation: Watson is the lead author of this collaborative work building on the global reach of the Talloires Network on civic and community engagement (which has over 300 university members worldwide with a combined enrolment of over 6m students).  It was launched at the 2011 Talloires Conference in Madrid.  It is credited with making a significant contribution to injecting Southern and Eastern perspectives into a scholarly tradition dominated by the North and West. Chris Duke has observed  in his review ?The book is to be commended for questioning dominant assumptions and turning the world at least of civic engagement upside down.?

Title: The once and future academic
AdditionalInformation: This is an invited chapter for a major international review volume. In 2013 the World Yearbook of Education focused on "Educators, Professionalism and Politics." In response the chapter offers both a summary and critique of the contemporary discourse about the academic profession.  As well as secondary analysis it draws on in the author's own research as highlighted in reports from the Higher Education Policy Institute (HEPI) and presented at meetings including the Presidential Address to the Society for Research into Higher Education and the House of Commons HEPI breakfast series.

Children's lives, children's futures: A study of children starting secondary school
DoubleWeightingStatement: The output is a major book based on a substantial ESRC funded research study of children beginning secondary school.  The study includes a large representative questionnaire survey in 15 schools and in depth personal interviews with about 40 children.  Individual chapters cover children’s sense of the future, their educational intentions, their occupational plans, their views of school, their experience as learners and negative responses to school.  Each of the six empirical chapters could easily be a journal article and the book overall addresses issues of social reproduction, the sociology of childhood, individualisation and structure and agency.

Language policy and education in Britain
VolumeTitle: Encyclopedia of language and education. 2nd edition
AdditionalInformation: This chapter was requested as an update of the 1st Edition published in 1998. The 10 volume award-winning encyclopedia represents a full revision and update of the field. The volume focuses on the political dimensions of language policy. The chapter is inter-disciplinary in perspective incorporating economics, politics, sociology of language, and language policy planning. Using a deconstructionist, critical discourse analysis (CDA) methodological approach, the chapter engages with the specific historical processes that have led to the hierarchizing of majority and minority languages and their speakers. The uniqueness of the chapter lies in the fact that in addition to language issues related to migrant and immigrant groups it extends the discourse on language and politics to the largely over-looked autochthonous languages of Scotland, Wales and Ireland, changes taking place within the European Union as well as the complex linguistic demands of the global economy. The main thesis of the chapter is that cultural and linguistic landscapes are not static; they evolve as societies undergo political, economic and demographic changes. Emphasizing the primacy of linguistic capital (Bourdieu) it explains the central role of language as both vehicle and mediator of contemporary social change and the central role that educational processes play in building effective human capital in a continuously changing world. It argues for the need of continued and deepening language in education research into limits and possibilities associated with contemporary change global processes.

Title: Considering heteroglossia in language and development in Sub-Saharan Africa
VolumeTitle: International Journal of the Sociology of Language
AdditionalInformation: The research question in this study was to examine how languages in Sub-Saharan Africa could be harnessed for social and economic development. Its theoretical framework is provided by postcolonial theory within a postmodernist analytical framework taking account of historical disjunctures, ambiguities and continuities in postcolonial policy discourse . It also considers their impact on national policy frameworks and the implications for social and economic development during a period of globalization and shifts within the labour process, the emergence of new economic markets and changed labour market needs. The study is underpinned by Bourdieu’s concept of linguistic capital exchange within linguistic markets and is extended to evaluate the validity of the notion of ‘language capital’ in local and international ‘language’ markets. Methodologically it is a conceptual-theoretical study based on critical discourse analysis derived from Foucault’s theory on power/discourse, framed by Bakhtin’s concept of heteroglossia, interpreted here within a sociological framework. The focus is on addressing a concrete social problem: the impact of language policy choices on under-development throughout Sub-Saharan Africa. The study is macro-level, using an inter-disciplinary framework to analyse the complex ways in which languages interact with everyday life, economic development and opportunities. The complex language ecologies of countries throughout Sub-Saharan Africa are considered and the emergence of indigenous language markets and their economic potential in cross-border trade.  The study examines the creole Langala and the evolution of the sub-cultural code ‘Sheng’ in Kenya, its widespread adoption by the youth, its harnessing by social healthcare agencies and its growing potential as an urban and cross-border trading language. The study argues for the official acknowledgement of ‘Sheng’ and corpus planning in order to harness such subcultural codes popular amongst the youth as a means of facilitating regional development. It was disseminated at a conference at the University of Khartoum, Sudan, 2013.

Title: The political economy of English language and development: English vs national and local languages in developing countries
VolumeTitle: English and international development: policy, pedagogy and globalization
AdditionalInformation: The research questions were how is language and development conceptualized in education and development academic discourse? How effective are these frameworks in addressing the complexities that surround language and development within the interactive global economic terrain? How effectively could language and development be addressed within an inter-disciplinary framework? Methodologically, this is a conceptual-theoretical study using critical discourse analysis derived from Foucault and Bakhtin to demonstrate the need for macro-language and development studies to adopt an inter-disciplinary framework incorporating subjects within the Humanities and Social Sciences to provide an integrated perspective of the role of language in social and economic development. In the tradition of CDA the study aimed to offer ‘a different mode or perspective of theorizing, analysis, and application throughout the whole field’. It examined theorization of language and development within discrete subject disciplines in the Humanities (sociolinguistics, language and culture) and in the Social Sciences (the sociology of language and the economics of language). These were juxtaposed with Bourdieu’s theory on the sociology and economics of language exchanges notably his concept of the exchange of linguistic and ‘language capital’ within different linguistic markets. Developing an inter-disciplinary framework, the study integrated concepts, theories and perspectives from sociolinguistics, language and culture, the sociology of language, development studies, macroeconomics politics, history and education. This framework was applied to postcolonial language policy, development discourse and empirical studies in the economics of language to analyse and reveal the limited nature and value of bounded subject-disciplines in the theorization of the role of language in social and economic development within the shifting cultural landscape, changing skills demands and economic opportunities evolving in the interactive global labour market.  The work has been disseminated widely, including a keynote address at the 2013 Inaugural International Conference, Language Sciences for Developing Countries, Lahore Women’s College University, Pakistan.

Title: Special Issue: New perspectives on transfer among bilinguals and L2 users
AdditionalInformation: Treffers-Daller took the initiative to organise the workshop on which the SI was based. The main aim was to bring together researchers in Second Language Acquisition and Bilingualism, as researchers working in these two fields are not always aware of each other's work. Both groups of researchers share an interest in the ways in whether or not bilinguals or L2 learners  can keep their languages separate. Traces of one language are often visible in spoken or written  products in the other language. This process is sometimes called transfer and sometimes crosslinguistic influence. Treffers-Daller took the lead in liaising with contributors, and approached the Editor of IJB with a proposal to publish a SI in the journal. She also wrote the introduction to the SI. In total she contributed 60% of the work towards the edition. The review process was shared with the second editor (40%). Treffers-Daller contributed one article to the SI.

Title: Special Issue: Knowledge and use of the lexicon in French as a second language
AdditionalInformation: Treffers-Daller was the lead editor of this special issue. The main aim was to bring together recent work into lexical aspects of French as a second language, which had not been covered in other recent volumes on L2 French. Treffers-Daller put the proposal together for the Editors of JFLS, approached the authors for contributions, led the review process, wrote the introduction and contributed one article to the SI. She did 80% of the work on this. The co-editors' role was to help with the reviewing process (20%).

Title:
Les Enseignants et le Genre: Les Inégalités Hommes-Femmes dans L’enseignement du Second
Degré en France et en Angleterre
EnglishAbstract: Drawing on feminist theories of work and education and a cross-national comparative perspective (Crompton 1999), this book explores gender inequalities in the teaching profession in England and France. It draws on 60 semi-structured interviews as well as on a range of secondary sources. Within each country, the narratives of men and women teachers were paralleled to identify gendered patterns, whether in relation to their career or domestic arrangements. A multi-level approach was favoured, which looked at the influence of national cultures and policies, teaching cultures and teachers’ working conditions, and individual biographies on gender equality.

Title: The societal construction of 'boys' underachievement' in educational policies: A cross?national comparison
Applied Musicology: Using Zygonic Theory to Inform Music Education, Therapy, and Psychology Research
DoubleWeightingStatement: Building on the findings of a dozen recent research projects, and four years in gestation, this monograph sets out a major new theoretical framework for undertaking research in music education, therapy and psychology. It is a work of considerable complexity, drawing as it does on diverse epistemologies from the arts and social sciences. At its heart, Applied Musicology involves the phenomenological analysis of around 100 instances of everyday musical engagement and interaction. These qualitative strands are drawn together quantitatively within novel frameworks of probabilistic modelling.

Substantial new research is presented in the book, including: the analysis of the relevance of the question under discussion; the analysis of policies of inclusive and special education in the UK and the US, and their underpinning philosophical theories; the analysis of equality and educational equality and the philosophical objections to the position defended in the book. Title: Understanding Learning Through Mental Model Theory
Technology and the Gendering of Music Education
DoubleWeightingStatement: This monograph explores the construction of gendered discourses in the music classroom through an examination of the digitally-mediated compositional processes of Key Stage 4 pupils in four schools. The process of enquiry consisted of a six month empirical multi-method ethnographic study, underpinned by an interdisciplinary theoretical framework. The study yielded important insights showing that, despite claims made for technology’s ‘democratising’ potential, gender significantly affects the ways in which students engage with technology. It showed the importance of acknowledging music composition as a socially embedded practice and failure to do so raises serious concerns about inclusion in the technologised classroom.

It contributes to evidence-based knowledge of what Catholic education has achieved and the challenges that it faces, having implications for the on-going debate about faith schools. Consequently, it contributes empirical research in the context of the discourse about the nature and purpose of contemporary Catholic education.

DoubleWeightingStatement: The School and institution advocate high quality teaching and learning, underpinned by excellence in research.  Between these two demands, this work consumed a significant proportion of research time and opportunity.  Significantly, this longitudinal study revealed the potential for change that exists in individual teachers’ practice, while also confirming their difficulty in challenging the status quo.  Research into teacher’s practice, pupils experiences and the changes needed to unite the two are both time intensive and concentrated in the researcher, requiring extended commitment.  The implications, disseminated internationally, give robustness to consequent changes in ITE provision, thus ensuring high quality teaching and learning.

DoubleWeightingStatement: The monograph articulates how school chaplains provide a necessary condition for the experience of God in Catholic schools.  The research draws upon narratives of practice and critically analyses the unique relationships that the chaplain holds, setting these within an ecclesiological structure.  The research examines and articulates the contribution of school chaplaincy to the mission and evangelisation of young people, elucidating its status as a primary ministry of the contemporary Church.  It demonstrates that in order to retain the “Catholicity” of Catholic education, the school chaplain is not a luxury but an essential part of the Catholic School.

AdditionalInformation: This paper largely focuses on the variation in additional fee income expenditure by as detailed in OFFA Access Agreements from different HEI types. It reveals not only variation in student support but in also the types of underrepresented social groups targeted by each institutions type. The paper discusses the potential impact on widening participation from what emerge as very divergent levels of engagement with underrepresented groups.

Title: Access agreements, widening participation and market positionality: enabling student choice?
VolumeTitle: The marketisation of higher education and the student as consumer
AdditionalInformation: This book chapter (for a book on the marketisation of higher education and the 'student as consumer') uses data derived from analysis of a sample of OFFA Access Agreements and sets it in a context of the historical development of the English HE system. It discusses the concept of widening participation as an emergent arena of institutions' marketing strategies and discusses the impact on student choice. (The themes of this work are currently being pursued by the author in HE Academy grant-funded research into the impact of student number controls, choice and competition on the English higher education landscape).

Achieving 'transparency, consistency and fairness' in English Higher Education admissions: progress since Schwartz?
AdditionalInformation: This paper is based on empirical research into changes to Higher Education admissions policy and practices in English Higher Education Institutions. It finds that institutional differentiation, as encouraged by an overtly market driven system, has increased since the Schwartz report and that, while transparency and consistency about admissions have been improved, that has not translated into systemic advances in making access to higher education fairer or the system more diverse.
