Title: How to communicate effectively with adult learners
VolumeTitle: IATED - Conference Proceedings, 6th International Conference of Education, Research and Innovations (ICERI2013), Seville, Spain, 18-20 November 2013
AdditionalInformation:
Published within Institutional Repository http://sure.sunderland.ac.uk/4255/

This research project contributed to the University of Sunderland gaining the Quality Assurance Agency (QAA) national award, 2013 Access to HE Higher Education Provider of the Year. The findings of the paper reveal that Higher Education Institutes (HEIs) need to rethink their communication strategies with adult learners. They need to offer added value pathways from FE to HE study, attractive solutions which respond to the need for agility and continuous change in both further and higher education. It also highlighted that transition from further to higher education study requires high-intensity support by academic and student-centred staff teams

Analyse du discours poststructuraliste. Les voix du sujet dans le langage chez Lacan, Althusser, Foucault, Derrida, Sollers
AdditionalInformation: The book provides an in-depth overview of the linguistic discourse tradition in France since the 1970s; in the second part, it sketches a polyphonic methodology which accounts for the way academic subject positions are constructed in written texts. The heart of the book is made up of five exemplary analyses of small textual fragments of Lacan, Althusser, Foucault, Derrida and Sollers, written around 1966, when the controversy over structuralism was at its peak.

Title: Le champ de la théorie : essor et déclin du structuralisme en France
AdditionalInformation:
100 word English Abstract: 
French thinkers such as Foucault and Derrida are often labeled as representatives of “poststructuralism.” Yet such an intellectual movement is unknown in France, where these theorists occupied positions too far apart to be
perceived as an intellectual group or movement. This study traces the evolution of the French intellectual field after the war when higher education institutions saw unprecedented growth. By drawing from Bourdieu's sociology of intellectuals , this study gives an account of the rise and decline of an intellectual generation which continues to leave its mark on the theoretical imagination of our time.

Title: Teaching and Researching Motivation
AdditionalInformation:
100 word English Abstract: 
Since the first edition by Dörnyei (2001), the language motivation field has changed significantly, reflecting the impact of language globalisation, shifting theoretical paradigms and alternative research methodologies – particularly, qualitative approaches I have long championed, for which reason I was invited as co-author. Thus this is largely a new book that has been completely rewritten to take account of major developments within the field, and includes a new 9,000–word chapter on current socio-dynamic and complex systems perspectives. Of the book’s four sections, I took primary responsibility for I, II and IV, and the discussion of qualitative research in III.

Second Language Learning Theories : third edition
AdditionalInformation: Please read chapters 4 and 5 of the book. The chapters are new additions to the book, and are lead authored by Marsden, edited by Mitchell and Myles, as noted in the introduction to the book. They provide a critical evaluation of cognitive explanations of second language learning phenomena and associated empirical work. The two previous editions of this book have not included most of the areas addressed by these two chapters, including implicit learning, usage-based emergentist approaches to language learning, O'Grady's efficiency driven processor, defining and measuring explicit knowledge, skill acquisition theory, role of different memory systems and attention. The chapters are unique in bringing these theories together and evaluating their explanatory power and their associated empirical base to date (other volumes, books, handbooks do not evaluate or integrate them as a whole).

AdditionalInformation: The Kenya research builds on research carried out in the UK on professional identities. The Arasa & Calvert (2013) uses a similar methodology as was used in the UK and the Calvert & Muchira (2013) uses only interviews. The purpose of this second study in another university was to see if  what we had observed in a secular established university might be replicated or reflected in a religious HE institution with a different culture, ethos, code of behaviour, student body and history. This accounts for some of the similarities in text between the two articles.

Deux cents ans apres la reforme d'Humboldt: Bologne. Ou va i'ensignement superier europeen?
EnglishAbstract: In the early 17th century Wilhem von Humboldt established the first research and teaching university in Europe; it was also the first modern university in the world. This famous university has had tremendous influence on all other universities. Higher education in Europe knows considerable changes again almost two hundred years later. The paper clarifies current, Bologna-related academic reforms in the light of the Humboldt-initiated reform. He not only introduced the research function within universities but also a new pedagogy. It was a challenge to traditional knowledge and expressed a new vision of knowledge recognizing all major academic activities.

Le New Labour et la troisième voie: une évolution de la politique de l'éducation pour une évolution de la classe moyenne
EnglishAbstract: This paper argues that New Labour’s ‘Third Way’ project – and the chaos that ensued – can only be understood by grasping the longstanding, complex and intimate relationship between education and the middle class. Drawing on empirical data from ongoing investigations into the allegiances of the middle class, the paper shows how New Labour’s desire to move beyond ‘left’ and ‘right, ‘state’ and ‘market’, ‘public’ and ‘private’, is best understood as an attempt to address the fears of a changing middle class. The paper concludes by discussing the implications of current crisis in the middle class for the future politics of education.
